name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 14 February 2019.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, before returning to work, I would like to express the European Parliament's condolences to the families of the victims of yesterday's tragic accident in Ethiopia, in which 157 people died, including many European citizens. Today marks the fifteenth anniversary of the terrorist attacks in Madrid, which killed 192 people and injured more than two thousand in 2004. 11 March has become a symbolic date: it is the day we dedicate to the memory of the victims of terrorism. As the cowardly attack on Strasbourg before Christmas reminded us, we cannot let our guard down. We must fight all the time and everywhere to defend our values and freedom from the barbarity of terrorism. Five years ago, Crimea was annexed by the Russian Federation. In its various resolutions, Parliament has pointed out that the annexation of Crimea is a violation of international law. The annexation violates the many agreements signed by the Russian Federation and Ukraine, notably the United Nations Charter, the Helsinki Final Act and the Budapest Memorandum. Today we reiterate our support for ukraine's independence and territorial integrity.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting of Thursday, 7 March 2019.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, according to Rule 22(4), you have the privilege to represent this Parliament in an official capacity. From 29—31 March, the World Congress of Families is going to take place in Verona. Maybe if they put your name on the website without your knowledge, that would be an explanation, but we would like to get a letter back from you.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I will repeat it to you for the umpteenth time: I will send you the answer in writing. However, the House is sovereign and matters much more to the House than a private letter between you and me.  I have received the invitation, I have not joined, I am going somewhere else: I do not know what we should do. I am not the Minister of the Interior and I cannot ban meetings in my country. If I go somewhere else, where the Prime Minister and Chancellor Merkel are, the answer seems to me to be more than clear. I do not know what needs to be done more than that.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I think the proposal is easily understandable. name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: – Mr President, yes indeed, I would like to speak against. I think it is unhelpful right now to change the title because we’re looking for a global new sanctions regime, and this is not focused on one country specifically. We’re also trying to build a coalition in Member States and in this House, and putting into the title the name ‘Magnitsky’ is not going to help that process. It is also out of focus as Magnitsky mainly focuses on corruption and financial fraud, whereas we’re trying to look at violations of human rights. There is no European legislation right now that actually has a name in it. Our legislation has boring names and there is actually no European Member State which officially has the word ‘Magnitsky’ in its sanctions regimes. Nor does Canada. Only the US has that, and that country does not allow redress and does not allow democratic oversight. I don’t think we should take an example out of that case, so we would like to have the title as it stands.

name: Antonio TAJANI

Following the outcome of the trilogue negotiations, the debate would be an opportunity for Parliament to show that it is indeed committed to the rights of people with disabilities and to express our expectation that Member States do much more in this area.

So I think that one more resolution, one more debate from this Parliament, will do nothing to resolve the serious situation in this country and I would add that if there are aficionados of the situation in Venezuela in this Parliament, I suggest that they collect the signatures for the establishment of a special committee on Venezuela, in which they will have the opportunity to debate the situation in that country. name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Framework Decision 2009/315/JHA, as regards the exchange of information on third-country nationals and as regards the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS), and replacing Council Decision 2009/316/JHA (COM(2016)0007 – C8—0012/2016 – 2016/0002(COD)) (A8-0219/2016), and – the report by Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a centralised system for the identification of Member States holding conviction information on third-country nationals and stateless persons (TCN) to supplement and support the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN system) and amending Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011 (COM(2017)0344 – C8-0217/2017 – 2017/0144(COD)) (A8—0018/2018).

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, sharing information across borders is essential to fight crime and terrorism in a world where people are increasingly mobile and cross-border crime is on the rise. The existing rules make it easier for non-EU nationals to hide crimes they have committed on EU soil than it is for EU nationals. This means that today, under the current European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS), there is an efficient and effective way to identify previous criminal convictions for EU nationals but not for third-country nationals. At present, officials who suspect a non-EU national has a criminal past can only find those convictions by individually asking all 27 other Member States. This means that previous criminal records are rarely found. It is a gaping legal loophole which leaves people in the EU less safe. This regulation is an important step to close these loopholes and improve information-sharing and cooperation between Member States in the fight against cross-border crime and terrorism. At the core, this is about ensuring judicial authorities have a complete picture when carrying out their work, meaning they can apply sentences fairly. We can all agree that non-EU nationals should not find themselves with more rights than EU citizens in the EU itself. Getting the right balance on this was important to all the groups, especially ensuring that there was no discrimination to EU nationals, who would be included if they had a third-country nationality as well. I believe that we have got this balance right and we won some significant safeguards in those negotiations, particularly regarding fingerprints. Our legal services see no discrimination in the text. This legislation closes the gap, while also providing a fair balance between protecting the rights of individuals and ensuring that past convictions are correctly attributed. We have ensured safeguards on how specific and targeted information can be shared. This is not a database that can simply be browsed through. There is no conviction data stored in the central database and so there is no differentiation of treatment between EU and third-country nationals, as both the EU and the third-country national systems ultimately result in the same outcome, i.e. that Member States’ judicial authorities are able to request previous criminal conviction information from the relevant Member State so that that can be taken into account for the sentencing of new convictions. Critically, the inclusion of dual nationals in this system means that nationals of both a third-country and an EU Member State can’t hide their past criminal convictions in the EU simply by disclosing only one of their passports. Let me be clear here as there is some misunderstanding, especially within the ALDE Group. This is for EU convictions only, so no Turkish convictions or convictions from any other non-EU Member State are involved – it’s only EU convictions. If we don’t have this system, authorities will have to make judgment calls on which system to search, and that would probably mean profiling based on race and name. I don’t believe we want to see that. In addition, the collection of the fingerprints for dual nationals will be exactly the same as for EU nationals. Overall, this is about ensuring judicial authorities have a complete picture in order to react adequately and to apply the right measures. Let me be clear, if colleagues here vote to reopen the deal you are putting your own citizens at risk. You are saying you want to discriminate against EU citizens in the EU, and you admit that you want some people to be able to hide serious criminal convictions, convictions which have been handed down on EU soil. This deal was voted through the LIBE Committee with a considerable majority. The Legal Services of all three institutions agree that there is no discrimination. It is a good agreement. We fought well and we got a lot in this Parliament, so I commend this to the Parliament, we should support it.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Daniel Dalton, and the respective Council Presidencies for the work done on the proposals for a regulation and directive on the system for the improved exchange of criminal records of third—country nationals, ECRIS—TCN. In particular, let me thank both co—legislators’ unceasing efforts to find a solution that is acceptable for all parties. The Commission proposed the ECRIS—TCN system following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015. The aim was to close loopholes in the existing system for the exchange of criminal records, which is ECRIS, by ensuring better access for Member States’ competent authorities to criminal records of third—country nationals. The proposals were included in the list of 2017 interinstitutional priorities for delivery before the European Parliament elections. With tomorrow’s vote, the European Parliament is delivering on this objective. As a result, we will achieve an improved system for the exchange of criminal records that contributes to the European area of freedom, security and justice. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadows in particular for their efforts to solve two main issues: first, the conditions under which fingerprints can be included in the ECRIS—TCN system; second, the inclusion of dual nationals, notably EU citizens who also hold the nationality of a third country. I am satisfied that we have found a balanced solution that is acceptable to all sides and that will ensure that the ECRIS—TCN system fulfils its purpose. The new system will allow the closing of loopholes in information exchange on previous convictions and this will be done on the basis of reliable identity information and with due regard to the rights of the individual. The Commission therefore fully supports the compromise found by the co—legislators and looks forward to tomorrow’s vote confirming it.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Thank you very much, Mr President. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur of the committee responsible for his excellent work, and also to the Commission for the very good cooperation in this case. This IT process that we are talking about today definitely needs to be updated —it needs to be expanded. Because at the moment this procedure is neither sufficient, in the sense that you get enough and good hits when you perform queries. In addition, the current procedure is also highly inefficient. It is estimated to cost up to EUR 78 million in costs in the Member States because it is just so cumbersome.  This new procedure will require us to spend around EUR 13 million on the EU side, and the Member States will have to spend the same amount again, but that is well-invested money, because we will get a better procedure for this afterwards, which will lead to a better security situation in the EU and also comply with all the requirements of the rule of law. I believe that this is precisely where the EU can show that it is on the right track and that it is there for the citizens of the EU.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to thank my colleague Mr Dalton for his work on this document. I believe that the cooperation between the European People's Party and the ECR has been a pillar of our success. I am pleased that, contrary to the Commission's proposal for 2016, the EU institutions are now aiming to create a centralised system. From the outset, I supported the creation of such a system, as the central system excludes technical problems and excludes possible misuse of information. I think it is safe to say that years of work are now over, because both the Commission and the Council have recognised that such a system is a key element of effective law enforcement, especially considering that the Schengen borders are also interoperable for law enforcement. I also think it is important that fingerprints will be part of the identification of third-country offenders, as they are more difficult to identify. Fingerprints are the most reliable way to accurately identify the person. I would like to stress that the security of citizens living in the European Union cannot be negotiable. For this reason, during the negotiations, I strongly advocated that the ECRIS-TCN system should not only cover third-country nationals who do not have EU nationality. I am convinced that all information relating to dual nationals who have the nationality of a third country in addition to the nationality of an EU Member State should be stored. The system must not contain loopholes. The European People's Party therefore supports this document because it considers it to be a significant step forward and we believe that it will create a workable system. Thank you very much.

name: Anna HEDH
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We are now on the final stages of working on these two proposals. It has been a long journey, which has become much more complicated than I first thought.  The basic objective of these proposals – that member states' criminal courts should be able to exchange information on convictions of third-country nationals with each other – is commendable. On the substance, our political group has no objection to the creation of a new information system to address shortcomings in the current system. On the other hand, we have seen problems with how the Commission and also the Council wanted to shape the system. Some of these have been resolved in the course of our work, but the main problem for us has been possible discrimination, and more concrete differences in treatment, between people who have only one European citizenship, people who have European citizenship plus citizenship of a country outside the Union and, finally, third-country nationals. The difference in processing is how many of the databases you are registered in and whether fingerprints should be taken. During the negotiations, we tried, together with alde, the Greens and the GUE, to put forward proposals for solutions based on objective criteria, but unfortunately we have not heard them during the negotiations.  It has also become apparent in the course of the hearing that the Commission had partly objectives other than simply putting in place a system for the exchange of convictions. Instead, what has been focused on is the future use of data in the context of so-called interoperability, that is, the interconnection of the EU information system. In the run-up to a European Parliament election in which far-right and racist parties are likely to move forward, it is important that we do not back down from fundamental principles. I am concerned that we are sending out signals that people who have citizenship of countries outside the Union may be treated differently. At the same time, I am basically in favour of a system for the exchange of convictions, but not in the way proposed. After lengthy reflection, as shadow rapporteur, I will recommend that our group abstain in the vote.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ecris is a database through which EU Member States can exchange information on convicted EU citizens. However, the Ecris database is not suitable for the exchange of information on convicted foreigners. Now we must always follow a bureaucratic agony to find out whether a non-European citizen has a criminal record or not. In concrete terms, the Justice Department must draw up 27 separate applications and send them to each EU Member State, with the result that this cumbersome procedure is barely followed. Foreigners with criminal records are about to walk.  Due to a lack of information, a Belgian court cannot currently take into account previous convictions in other EU Member States. This is an unacceptable gap for us. Foreigners with criminal histories must be dealt with as harshly as Belgians or EU citizens with similar criminal histories. With the proposal before us, we want to adapt European legislation in this way to simplify the exchange of data on condemned non-European citizens. A central database will keep track of which foreigners have been convicted in which Member State, after which the authorities can quickly request additional information. This dossier is an excellent example of the added value that the European Union can offer. The N-VA is satisfied with the outcome of the negotiations. For example, fingerprints were included in the proposal to facilitate the identification of persons and also people with dual nationality are included in the database. We therefore fully support this legislative package.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking our rapporteur, Mr Dalton, and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for all their work on this rather technical and very sensitive proposal. It has been a long walk that has brought us here today, and I am very sad to tell you that I cannot support the outcome of the trilogue negotiations on the regulation. I am deeply disappointed at the decision to include dual nationals in the ECRIS-TCN system. From the beginning, this was clearly a red line for me as the shadow rapporteur for the ALDE Group in Parliament. It is alarming that the Council has not been able to prove the necessity or the proportionality of such a far-reaching measure. This only proves that their arguments about dual nationals trying to hide their EU nationality are completely unfounded. The significant difference in treatment between EU nationals, non-EU nationals and dual nationals introduced by the proposal is clearly discriminatory. It has been described as differentiated treatment: with all due respect, that is a description for alternative facts. ECRIS-TCN, as proposed now, fails to respect fundamental rights and non-discrimination and it also violates primary Union law. If the proposal is adopted as it stands it will result, for the first time, in a large category of Union citizens being treated under Union law no longer as Union citizens but as nationals of third countries. De facto, this proposal will introduce the idea of first-class and second-class Union citizens. I will vote against this and I would ask and urge the other political groups to do the same.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Here we have the case of an EU-wide database, which we, as green civil rights activists, did not immediately reject, such as the collection of passenger data declared inadmissible by the European Court of Justice. ECRIS is not about mass surveillance, but about the retrievability of data on convicted criminals. This index already exists for EU citizens. It is only logical to finally set it up for third-country nationals who have been convicted in the EU. And yet, in the end, we will not be able to support the result. ECRIS for third-country nationals, as it is now to be decided, and as Mr Dalton negotiated with the Council against the mandate of most LIBE coordinators, does not lead to equal treatment for third-country nationals, but to double unequal treatment: while FINGERPRINTs are only recorded in ECRIS by EU citizens if they have already accrued in the course of the investigation, the fingerprints of third-country nationals should always be taken from a certain threshold. This has a system and is another building block of a comprehensive biometrics database of all third-country nationals, which we not only categorically reject. Dual nationals, i.e. people who hold both EU citizenship and those of a third country, are to be included in ECRIS and ECRIS-TCN. So, "as a precaution," they end up in two databases instead of one. As a result, some EU citizens are less equal than others, and it is therefore contrary to the prohibition of discrimination on grounds of nationality. Although we would have welcomed ECRIS-TCN in principle, unfortunately, the result is not good enough in this case. We cannot accept structural discrimination against third-country nationals and dual nationals.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, in view of the terrorist threat to Europe in recent years, the security issue is extremely important for both European citizens and us lawmakers, who have a duty to make every corner of Europe safe. Over the years, a number of measures have been taken to increase the security of citizens. One of them is the establishment of the ECRIS system for the exchange of information on convictions of third-country nationals, which we must approve this week. Such a system already exists for European citizens, but its absence for third-country nationals has so far been a breach of European internal security. The effective exchange of information on the convictions of third-country nationals issued by European courts will mean that no one can escape the law anymore by moving from one country of the European Union to another. Let me be clear – freedom of movement does not mean discharge. All people living in the European Union, whether European citizens or not, have an obligation to comply with national and European laws. If not, they must suffer the consequences. The new system will ensure that this liability will take place regardless of the place of residence.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the Union was conceived and has long functioned as a space of security, but in the circumstances of the financial and migration crisis it has proved insufficient to protect citizens from internal and external threats. It was often spared the wrong things and under the aegean of human rights allowed various criminals, extremists and terrorists to spread the tentacles of their octopus around Europe. There was a lukewarm response, usually when innocent people and their property were already going to get hurt. Today we face a new great challenge, namely the return of ISIL fighters to their European homelands after the so-called caliphate lost the bulk of its territory. The proposals in these two reports will strengthen technical cooperation and enable the competent authorities to make informed decisions more quickly. I believe in national institutions, our security professionals and their cooperation, and I hope that politics and political correctness will not stand in the way of protecting the citizens of Europe from danger.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As a member of the Committee on Terrorism, I draw attention to the numerous – I stress numerous – loopholes that exist regarding the security of citizens in the European Union. I am pleased that today one of these gaps will be closed. In fact, we will be voting on two legislative proposals on this issue, on this issue, which has been described quite well. And I'll remind you. On the one hand, we will close the legal loophole, on the other hand, we will update the register, which is very important and very important for the knowledge of those who deal with security. Thirdly, we will eliminate some existing discrimination immediately. In my opinion, all work should merit recognition and be voted on by an overwhelming majority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Criminal Records Information System, ECRIS, is a system already in place for the exchange of information in relation to convicted citizens of the European Union. It is therefore very logical to extend this system to third-country citizens as well. It is not possible for foreigners to be treated better than citizens of the European Union. The question arises as to what will happen to those who have dual citizenship.  I should point out to colleagues that dual citizenship means dual rights, but also dual obligations. You cannot, when you are a third-country citizen and a citizen of the European Union, simply have the positives of a third-country citizen and not the obligations. It is therefore possible for those who have dual citizenship to give up the nationality of a third State or, if they have dual citizenship, will have both the positive and the negative. Mr Dalton's proposal must therefore be implemented.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would agree on the sensitive and at the same time important issue of the inclusion of dual EU/third-country nationals. For the Commission it is vital to include in the ECRIS—TCN system all third-country nationals, including those who are also EU nationals, otherwise we would leave an important loophole and undermine the objective of the proposal. What we have to avoid is that criminals play off different nationalities to hide possible previous convictions. We recognise that this establishes a different approach between EU citizens who only have an EU nationality and those also holding the nationality of a third country. However, we consider this is justified by the fact that the latter can use either of these nationalities when confronted with a prosecution, or in other cases where their previous criminal record might hamper them. For example, if the persons concerned had already been convicted for a sexual offence under their TCN nationality, they might use only their EU nationality when applying for a position involving working with children in another Member State. Excluding persons with EU/third-country nationality would mean that the identity data of certain persons with a criminal record, who hold the nationality of a third country, would not be stored in the ECRIS—TCN system. I would like to thank you for your interventions. I would like to encourage you to vote in favour of the compromise texts of both proposals. The new system for the exchange of criminal records is an important contribution to the security union and to the European justice area.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their comments, and to thank all the shadow rapporteurs on these proposals because we did a lot of work together and it was a long process: thank you all for your work. I would also particularly like to thank Javier Nieto Perez, policy advisor to my political group, and Harriet Carr, from my office, for the long hours and the work they put in. On dual nationals, I repeat my previous comments: the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission have all confirmed that the inclusion of dual nationals is not discriminatory. Ensuring there was no discrimination was one of my key priorities: we worked long and hard together to get the requisite changes to the text to ensure there was no discrimination. To the ALDE Group and the Green Group, and particularly to Ms Mlinar, for whom I have the greatest respect and with whom we have been working very closely on this, I must say I believe you are mistaken. By aligning the collection of fingerprints for all EU nationals, regardless of whatever extra nationality they may have, we have ensured that the treatment for everyone is exactly the same. There is no second-class EU citizenship here. If some groups wish to use this legislation as a political tool, and to tell the world that an academic and legally dis-proven debate is more important than the welfare of our citizens or the effective functioning of our judicial systems in the EU, there is nothing I can do to stop them. However, let’s be clear what they are doing: they are allowing third-country nationals to avoid their convictions being known in the EU, and that is putting all of us at risk of serious crime and terrorism. These are people with criminal convictions, remember. We are faced with one question tomorrow. Do you really think that criminals who are non-EU nationals should be able to hide their criminal convictions from our courts when EU nationals cannot do that? I don’t think they should.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 12.3.2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Where necessary – and this is an area in which it should not go beyond what is necessary – the transmission of information on citizens' criminal records should be carried out on a bilateral basis, to be established between the States concerned. This European system goes beyond that, entering a recognised sensitive area, because it is associated with individual rights, freedoms and guarantees, with acceptance in the constitutional acquis of some Member States. Going beyond what is necessary, this system creates problems. It emphasizes the attempt to move towards the federalization of justice. Putting data from citizens of the Member States in the hands of supranational institutions – which are not exactly references in safeguarding individual rights and freedoms. No clear guarantees as to the protection of this data.  All this in the context of a security drift, driven from a broad and dubious definition of terrorism, and migration policies aimed at punishing secondary movements and facilitating expulsion. A more example of how the views and conceptions of the far right are making their way, by the hand of the right and social democracy.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Michaela Šojdrová report, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the 'European Solidarity Corps' programme and repealing the [European Solidarity Corps Regulation] and Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 375/2014 (COM(2018)0440 – C8-0264/2018– 2018/0230(COD)) (A8-0079/2019).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, six months have elapsed since we last gathered here to discuss the European Solidarity Corps 2018—2020. Here we are again with an even stronger youth programme. Our task was complicated by the fact that we could not rely on implementation data from the ongoing European Solidarity Corps as such data was not available. However, with the help of stakeholders, we were able to identify areas which could be further improved. I am also glad that all political groups maintained the same shadow rapporteurs so we could continue with our previous excellent cooperation, and I would like to thank them for this. Some 332 amendments were tabled and four committees issued opinions, so there were many ideas on the table. Despite this, we managed to achieve a broad majority and the final report was approved with only one vote against and one abstention. The Commission proposal provides us with a budget of EUR 1 260 000 000, which we endorsed. It is necessary in order to meet the objective of activities for over 350 000 participants over the course of seven years. It is also needed since the European Solidarity Corps will newly integrate the former EU Aid Volunteers programme, providing possibilities to volunteer in third countries struck by a humanitarian crisis. Volunteering and humanitarian aid should enable participants to express their solidarity in more ways, and the EU to express more solidarity towards third counties. In order to be successful, the European Solidarity Corps needs greater visibility. During discussions with young people, I realised that most of them, even if involved in youth organisations, are still not aware of the programme, so this is where ambassadors could be of help. Former participants could share their experience with other young people in schools, youth organisations and other gatherings, thus spreading awareness and encouraging others to participate. The programme should also be promoted through dynamic means such as social media. We also propose a European Solidarity Corps ‘Infoday’, which would serve to reinforce promotion activities. In order to increase the programme’s visibility, it is also necessary to attract more organisations active in the solidarity field and encourage them to become participating organisations. We must not, however, sacrifice quality for quantity. Activities must be high quality and meet the expectations and needs of young people. It is important that quality labels are differentiated too. It’s crucial to empower stakeholders. We should give them more space to engage in the implementation of the programme. We must not forget that the European Solidarity Corps was designed as a programme for young people. Therefore, in principle, the programme should remain open to people up to the age of 30. I respect that humanitarian aid should allow participation regardless of age. However, the aim of the programme is to empower youth so other solidarity activities must stay limited to the participation of young people. We have to give greater thought to ensuring that the programme is also accessible to people with fewer opportunities. I am convinced that together we have set a very good basis for the negotiations with the Council. Many practical aspects of the programme will be determined through implementation, so I am also counting on the Commission’s dedication and continuous support. For me, the European Solidarity Corps is a springboard for volunteering in the EU. I believe that volunteering should be mainstreamed through the other EU programmes. I would again like to thank all colleagues and I am looking forward to continued discussion and a successful vote.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. Mr President, the establishment of the European Solidarity Corps will be the cornerstone of European solidarity and volunteering and will develop the spirit of solidarity and volunteering among European young people. The ESE Programme offers young people the opportunity to participate in solidarity programmes to address social challenges in the field of humanitarian aid.  Our recommendation, however, is that the 30-year age limit should not be applied in the field of humanitarian aid, to allow more experienced people to assist in the effort, because it often requires special training and knowledge before taking office. There are also concerns about the distribution of the budget in the various aspects and, for this reason, we, on behalf of the Committee on Development, have tabled amendments to this end in order to ensure adequate funding for all humanitarian aid activities.  The failures of the European Union's previous voluntary action programmes must not continue. We want to have a successful European Solidarity Corps. I welcome the proposed simplified procedures for the quality label for the participating organisations, as well as the registration of the participants already involved. I know first-hand the huge issues with bureaucratic procedures and I hope they will be simplified.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I’m glad to join you today for this plenary debate on the European Solidarity Corps. This programme is still quite young but it is growing quickly and young people across Europe are keen to get involved. The European Solidarity Corps has the potential to become another iconic programme like Erasmus. Solidarity among citizens and Member States is one of the key values on which our Union is built. The European Solidarity Corps offers young people opportunities to live that solidarity and to experience what being European feels like, and they are eager to take these opportunities. One hundred and thirteen thousand young people have now signed up for this initiative. Almost 12 000 of these have already started their solidarity activities. This proves that the programme is responding to a clear demand on the ground. Young people are making a real difference, supporting individuals and whole communities in need. This is why, in June 2018, the Commission proposed to continue and further expand the European Solidarity Corps under the next multiannual financial framework. We want to keep the main thrust of the current programme, but extend its scope after 2020 so that we can also support humanitarian aid operations beyond the EU’s borders. I want to express my thanks for the great dedication with which the rapporteur – Ms Šojdrová –, and the shadow rapporteurs have taken this work forward. I would also like to thank Ms Theocarous for her work as the rapporteur in the Development Committee, particularly looking at the new humanitarian aid operations. The Commission welcomes the strong support of the European Parliament for the proposal and takes note of the amendments that it put forward. I am very pleased to see that we have common ground on almost all aspects of the programme.  One important point where we differ and where we still need to find agreement is the new humanitarian aid stand and, more specifically, your wish to open it up to people of all ages.  Let me underline that the European Solidarity Corps is a youth programme, designed specifically to offer fresh opportunities to the young generation, to invest in their development, their skills, their dreams, and the idea is to bring all of these opportunities together in one place. In fact, the activities of the programme are limited to young people aged up to 30 for good reason: to help them in their transition to adulthood and independence and to the labour market, while obtaining a solidarity experience. Thirty is not an arbitrary age limit; it is based on evidence. Above this age, the vast majority of people have settled in their professional and private life. The demand is already high in the age group up to 30. Removing the age limit would mean taking away opportunities for young people and we risk job substitution. Moreover, the activities falling under the new humanitarian aid strand will account for only 4 500 of the 350 000 opportunities that we want to offer under the European Solidarity Corps over 7 years, and only 500 of these are expected to be taken up by people above 30. Introducing different eligibility criteria for such a small share of activities would lead to disproportionate extra administrative costs and make the programme more complicated, threatening to shut out those who we want to benefit most: young people. I would therefore plead with you to keep the European Solidarity Corps a real youth programme. Having said this, the Commission would be keen to start negotiating with you right away, as is the Council. This is my personal commitment and offer to you. I’m ready to work with you towards an agreement before the end of the current parliamentary term. Partial first reading agreements have already been reached for quite a number of future programmes. It would be a pity if the European Solidarity Corps, this new flagship programme for young people, were to be left behind. I am sure that the good compromise we reached on the current regulation only very recently would greatly facilitate negotiations. A swift agreement would help the Commission to make all the preparations to ensure that the programme can be fully and effectively implemented right from the start of 2021, but most importantly, it would send a clear signal to Europe’s young generation that investing in them remains a priority for us, and that we want to do what we can to enable them to make the most of their lives and build a better Europe for the future.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Commissioner, young people who are also here today! Since 2016, thanks to the European Solidarity Corps, young people have been given the opportunity to make their contribution to society across Europe, through volunteering, traineeships or in their workplaces, thus showing solidarity. The ESC is more than a voluntary service, it creates cross-border identity and values. It is therefore right that, in the next period, we want to raise EUR 1.2 billion for young people in order to support this programme. At this stage, we need more young Europeans who live democracy and solidarity. I therefore warmly welcome the fact that young people are taking to the streets across Europe to demonstrate for more climate protection at the Fridays for Future and for demonstrating for freedom on the Internet. Young people are not bots, and that's why this program is just the thing. With this programme, we support the future of the European Union, and I am pleased that we want to take the money into our hands.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the REGI Committee. Mr. Chairman, congratulations to the reporters. Young people often ask about volunteering opportunities. They want to contribute to society in their free time and help people in need, be it natural disasters such as fires, floods or earthquakes that unfortunately, especially in recent years, we have faced to other different humanitarian activities.  I am pleased that in the 2021-2027 budget we are increasing funding for this programme from €376 million to €1.3 billion so far, more than three times. What is important is that participating in the program must be simple. That is why I suggested using a simplified method of costing for those participating, and participants need to reimburse all costs related to volunteering activities. It is important that participants are young, of course, which is what we talked about, but especially that the program is open and accessible for young people who are not in employment, education or training.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Solidarity Corps is an offer for young Europeans, for young people. It is built on the basis of previous experience gathered on other projects that this project combines. That is a very good thing – it is good that it will simplify bureaucracy, reduce administrative costs, lead to greater clarity in such projects, and make everything that forms the framework of volunteering more flexible today. On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to two points which, from my point of view, are crucial. Firstly, there is no doubt that this project needs to be proposed, it requires good information, it requires, first of all, it requires giving young people what this project is about, what it entails and what its prospects are. I am pleased that this seven-year period already has financial guarantees, that we have a budget built, that we have a certain framework. On the other hand, practice– I stress – practice in the implementation of this project is today, from my point of view, the most important challenge, and it will determine whether this project will meet its hopes.  Finally, I wanted to thank my colleague Šojdrová – more than three hundred amendments could spoil our document in the final. This has not happened, it is a good document and we can vote on it safely tomorrow.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, my fellow rapporteur, Mr Šojdrová, my fellow shadow rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, I think that the signal we are giving to the citizens of Europe, two months before the European elections, is very important. Two very strong messages.  The face of Europe is also decidedly that of volunteering, solidarity and active citizenship. And this must once again be a watchword of the European Union, especially from the new generations. We must make this experience stable over the next 7 years, which had already begun in recent years and which had included the European voluntary service, which in twenty years had, however, involved one hundred thousand young people. We certainly want to be bolder. With tomorrow's vote on the establishment of the European Solidarity Corps, for which I was shadow rapporteur in the Group of the Party of European Socialists and European Socialists, we are taking an important step forward because we are going to establish a stable Union programme within the framework of the next MFF and I hope that the Council of Ministers will accept the proposal – also in terms of budget – that Parliament has made. Almost all will be devoted (almost 86 %) of its budget for voluntary activities, active citizenship and solidarity for young people between the ages of 18 and 30, 8 % of the quota will go to traineeships and work, but in the context of non-profit activities, and 6 % will go to humanitarian aid, collecting an important inheritance, without an age limit similar to the other. This is a political step, which we really must tell young people who do not know it. I think it is important to think about the fact that, symbolically, this will be of the utmost importance. I remember. I met them, as the Commissioner met them, in Norcia, after a terrible earthquake: a nucleus of young volunteers from twelve countries – it had enormous significance. More than 70 000 young people have already registered on the dedicated online portal; 7 000 are already participating in social inclusion, migrant integration, support for local communities and cultural heritage. It is important that for the next seven years the budget has been increased to more than one billion, confirming as a political priority this fundamental value of the European Union, in order to respond above all to the needs of society, communities, promoting the personal and professional development of young people, civic, with particular attention to the most disadvantaged. That is why we wanted to make it more inclusive, for children with fewer opportunities, for example those who have disabilities, health, difficulties even in the school field or come from a migratory context or from marginalized communities.  I am very pleased that some very important aspects have been taken up. The first is the European dimension of experience: all these activities must be transnational in nature, they must not overlap with national voluntary schemes but, on the contrary, they must support countries that do not need to achieve this. Country activities must also have this transnational dimension.  And then, above all, we have expanded to social enterprises and organizations also private, but always for non-profit activities and with the possibility of having a diversified quality mark for the types of insertion.  I will end by saying that this is a new experience that gathers the best in the past, but that it also wants to have the will to build a citizenship from below. I think that today we need to talk a lot about this, about institutional reforms of Europe, about political integration and about building processes of active citizenship.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Solidarity Corps in its new version as a one-stop shop which brings together all the possibilities for young Europeans to participate in solidarity programmes is a reality that we will be proud of in a few years. A great idea, as was the Erasmus programme, because it will equalize the opportunities for access to these programmes and because it will make better use of the resources we devote to them and promote a more comprehensive and objective assessment of the impact these activities have on the people who benefit from them.  Thus, the noblest values on which our Union is founded will be systematically converted into facts. Our young people are going to contribute to the cohesion of our society, they will help the people who need them, they will know other realities that will make them more aware, more supportive, they will be vaccinated against stereotypes and prejudices, and they will acquire skills that will help them as citizens and in their possibilities of employability.  That is why I agree on the need to improve definitions of solidarity and volunteering and to increase outreach measures by applying the means that best reach young people to the task. I also advocate improving the quality and accuracy of the certifications obtained by the participants and I propose that in this concept, "participants", be included the companions who highlight the civil organizations that make possible the operation of this program. Its role is to make everything work and is a double exercise in solidarity with the final recipients of the programme and with the young people who participate in it.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had. This new Erasmus Solidarity Corps programme has the potential to become one of the European Union's great success stories. It answers the question of how we can show more solidarity in the European Union. And it is above all about young people between the ages of 18 and 30, who, with a wide range of voluntary solidarity services in theatres, migrants, refugees, environmental protection, climate policy – wherever organisations propose this or where they themselves have ideas, what they can do for the European Union and for themselves. They learn languages, they get to know other countries. They learn empathy and they learn to hold the European Union together and, at the same time, to do something for themselves. They develop their personality , so it is what we can call a win-win situation in the best sense of the word.  Fortunately, the European Commission has now proposed to increase this programme, which was now in the order of 375 million, to 1.2 billion in the budget. In other words, there is a very clear political will here, more for solidarity in the EU, for more to be done for young people and to make it clear to all those involved why it makes sense to stand up for other people in THE EU's municipalities, but also for the idea of the European Union as a whole, because it is a positive idea and because it is a solidarity – that is, a really good programme.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the Commission's proposal for the European Solidarity Corps proves, once again, that the European Union uses the concepts of volunteering and solidarity only by tool and euphemism. The programme was set up in such a way that the very concept of solidarity is distorted. It establishes a dangerous link between volunteering and employability, while essentially trying to impose covert work, while also promoting the participation of for-profit companies in it.  The objectives of the solidarity programme cannot be entrepreneurship, profits and precarious work for young people. Such a programme must strengthen the common value of solidarity and not lead to the deconstruction of its content. To energize citizens and help young people in their personal development and not to boost the profits of multinationals. The European Solidarity Corps, ladies and gentlemen, as it is set up, is another ideological and political mechanism under the control of the neoliberal European Union.  Today's European Union has proven to be unable to meet the real needs, the needs of young people for education, for work, for dignity. It is unable to cope with the enormous economic and humanitarian crises caused by its neoliberal policies, policies which must be overturned and not addressed with these patches that we are discussing today.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, what would the start of a week in the European Parliament be without a brand new, highly expensive, somewhat sinister-sounding scheme? It’s lovely to be back, it’s good: I feel like I am back here, seeing one of these things. I like the fact, Commissioner, that you are now constructing policy based on The Midwich Cuckoos. That’s a great idea. What we have here is Big Brother, dressed in a halo. You are allowed to go and do some work and you are brought together, and this money – a mere EUR 1.2 billion by the way at a time when we are told everyone is struggling with austerity – goes into EU-approved good schemes. You can volunteer to do these good things as long as you learn to have solidarity: that you are all good little Europeans working together. Even the speakers in favour of it make no secret whatsoever of the fact that this is a political programme! Solidarity across borders, breaking down stereotypes, that is lovely, but there are charities that people can volunteer to work with to do good works without this political angle. This, as one of the speakers said, is ‘another Erasmus’. Yes, another Erasmus! Another scheme whereby we dress up something good, like education, but dose it so full of EU propaganda that it is almost impossible to see truth from what is made up. This is exactly the kind of idea that turns people off, and that worries people. You are trying to indoctrinate people, Commissioner, and that’s why you don’t want older people involved. You want young minds to manipulate at an early age. This is a crazy waste of money, it is a very poor tribute to The Midwich Cuckoos, and it is a great start to the week: you have really got me fired up, so I want to thank you for that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have tried by pleading to contradict this project that has been talked about and spoken about well and correctly. I ask you what you mean by solidarity and whether you think solidarity is needed? And, you have also said, among other things, that this project worries people. Why do people worry? Because it is a well-designed project that actually wants to train young people as volunteers for this purpose. Please answer me!

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card answer. – I see solidarity as something different from the way you see it. I think solidarity, in this EU context, means one European people – it means no difference between all of us, brought together and homogenised. That’s what I see solidarity here as meaning. I would like to see the use of the word ‘solidarity’ to mean real solidarity, in times of difficulty, times when we work together, but this solidarity is a complete denunciation of individuality, of the nation state, and of all the things that made us all individually great in the past.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union is intervening by all means against the people, by enlisting bombings, trade wars, tariffs, sanctions, so-called human rights clauses and threats. The European Solidarity Corps is another reactive multi-tool to support the European Union's complex military structures, such as PESCO. It is a body of unemployed people, all of them caused by the policies of the European Union and its governments, which will be the dead, refugees and the wreckage of the imperialist interventions of the European Union and its allies as well. From country to country, even outside the European Union, they will go to collect certificates of volunteering and short-term apprenticeships with an allowance equal to their expenses, with NGO contractors and businesses. So with a lot of tartars; imperialist interventions, eurotrust infiltration, expansion of galleon industrial relations, recycling of unemployment, trade in supposed solidarity, single-balance all for big capital.  Young workers, with a strong Communist Party, can respond to imperialist plans and the working jungle.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, as permanent rapporteur of this Parliament for humanitarian aid, I welcome this Regulation on the European Solidarity Corps, which has been part of the humanitarian initiative that has existed since 2014.  I think there are two fields that come together or meet here. On the one hand, the need to respond to the growing humanitarian crises in the world—most of them man-made as a result of wars, clashes, but increasingly as a result of climate change: droughts in large parts of the world, hurricanes, floods, fires of all kinds. On the other hand, the need to build a sense of belonging – of solidarity – to young people and non-young people in the European Union, who can intervene to alleviate suffering in all these areas where humanitarian aid is needed. I have heard before that this is an Erasmus, and it has been said dismissively. Erasmus is the best the European Union has ever built. But this is not an Erasmus. An Erasmus benefits young people, who have an educational opportunity. This is a solidarity of young people with others who suffer from a situation of need. The difference is no less. The difference is absolute.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, at its core, the European Solidarity Corps stands for the values that the EU was built upon. It is therefore a peace-making solidarity project, which invests in the potential of young citizens. I’m a supporter of the initiative and I’m very pleased with the report as voted in the Committee on Culture and Education. I advocated for an enhanced budget in order to make the programme available to all young European citizens, especially those with fewer opportunities. Being able to volunteer in solidarity actions from a young age with proper support offers many benefits. The EU Solidarity Corps will provide opportunities for 17-30-year-olds to take an active role in helping communities in crisis, whilst developing vocational skills and personal attributes such as self-confidence and empathy. As an MEP for the UK, I’m sad that my young constituents may not have access to this fantastic programme because of Brexit. At a time when so many young people feel disenfranchised from politics, the European Solidarity Corps has the potential to further involve our youth in their communities and strengthen their role as active citizens. Being part of this programme is an opportunity that can transform lives, and it is one of the many benefits that UK youth might lose because of a vote in the UK in 2016 that was largely the result of older people’s dissatisfaction, a vote about the past, not about the future.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – I very much hope that the new European Solidarity Corps will have real added value for young people in the European Union in the next programming period. For this to happen, I think we need to take into account two very important aspects. On the one hand, we need to make sure that the Corps has a sufficiently ambitious budget for more young people to have access to volunteering activities and to feel socially useful.  On the other hand, it must also be accessible to every young person, regardless of their economic and social status. Young people with more modest financial opportunities, those living in remote regions and people with disabilities should not be overlooked, as happens with other European programmes. This will be the measure of the success of this program. Last but not least, I believe that regulating volunteering at European level will finally give impetus to the adoption of legislation in my country – Bulgaria. There are many voluntary organizations in Bulgaria that have been waiting for this to happen for years. I hope we don't let them down once again.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the text dismissed by the Committee on Culture defines solidarity as a sense of responsibility on the part of all, towards all, to commit themselves to the common good, which is expressed through concrete actions without expecting anything in return.  With the European Solidarity Corps, the European Union achieves the dual objective of promoting solidarity as a value, mainly through volunteering, and of increasing the participation of young people as a means of helping to strengthen social cohesion, solidarity, democracy, European identity and active citizenship in the Union and abroad.  We broadly support the objectives introduced by the European Parliament of social inclusion through a clear definition of young people with fewer opportunities, which also includes disability, and that of a solid and significant component of learning and training in the course of volunteering, useful for carrying out a subsequent professional activity.  That's a good sign. Thousands of young people aged 18 to 30 will therefore have the opportunity to engage in solidarity projects through voluntary activities, internships and work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, volunteering and solidarity really are important values in modern society. The point is, however, that, observing the proposal for the famous European Solidarity Corps, what we are seeing is that this is not the case, because volunteering is an activity that is done without pay. Here we see that EUR 1.2 billion will be allocated for this famous volunteering – it is paid volunteering, that is. Secondly, is it volunteering on the basis of solidarity? I very much question this because we have seen how the famous NGOs have acted in relation to support for the refugee issue. We saw a big party, which is currently taking place in Greece and the other countries. The case of volunteering solidarity in practice is therefore being used to continue the famous party that takes place in the field of refugees, migration and other actions of society and, of course, to cover up the great problem of unemployment. If we want to take action, let us give this money in favour of strengthening the employment of young people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, indeed, it was very good to feel the broad support across the chamber for this initiative. The European Solidarity Corps has been a very successful initiative. If you want to keep the pace and the success of this initiative, we have to step forward and we have to start the trilogues in order to keep this success for the next multiannual financial framework.  I again express the European Commission’s readiness to start the trilogues as soon as possible, and I ask you to help our partners during the trilogues and let’s make this success story a sustainable success story. Let me once again thank Ms Šojdrová for her report and let me commend your work and your support in this project.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for this debate which I believe was very fruitful. I appreciate the fact that we share almost the same position and I am convinced that the changes that Parliament is proposing will improve the programme. I hope that the Council will welcome them as well and that we will reach an ambitious agreement. We all want the European Solidarity Corps to provide quality activities for volunteers and for former participants to continue to engage in these volunteer activities. This European programme can, for thousands of citizens and young people, give birth to new commitments, new knowledge and experiences. I hope that solidarity will empower not only the beneficiaries of the activities, but also the volunteers and, ultimately, society.  This is an opportunity for citizens, but also for society as a whole. Solidarity should not be seen as a luxury product, but as a whole that each of us should at least try to include in our lives. I believe that this program brings us closer to achieving that goal. Thank you very much for your cooperation.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 March 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Solidarity is at the basis of the European project, as well as enshrined in the Treaties, and for this reason it must be preserved and cultivated. The European Solidarity Corps is a programme that goes in this direction and is therefore undoubtedly to be appreciated and valued. It offers a concrete opportunity for young people to mature, both personally and professionally, helping local communities in difficulty. Specifically, I would have preferred only non-profit organisations to be able to participate in the programme, to avoid, for example, possible abuses by multinationals that do not need public money to clean up their image. The so-called employment part (traineeships and jobs) also leaves me a little perplexed, as it risks debasing a noble activity such as volunteering and encouraging low-cost replacement practices for the workforce. Fortunately, I have succeeded with my proposals in increasing guarantees and safeguards by introducing a clear dividing line between volunteering and work activities, as well as strict control procedures that can exclude organisations that have broken the rules from the programme. We cannot allow the high rates of unemployment caused, among other things, by draconian austerity policies, to legitimise the exploitation of our young people in any way.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – I congratulate my fellow Member Sojdrova on the preparation of this report. The European Solidarity Corps aims to give young people even more opportunities to participate in volunteering work for the benefit of certain communities or society as a whole throughout Europe. Valuable abilities can be acquired by young people who feel compelled to help others, to acquire new knowledge and skills. The programme will enable around 350,000 young people to volunteer, e.g. in restoring disaster zones, helping children or the elderly, or for charitable purposes. 86% of the planned budget is for voluntary activities, but also for traineeships and short-term employee activities. According to the EP's proposal, the programme will also include young people with 'fewer opportunities', i.e. young people with disabilities and health problems, people from minorities or young people from convergence regions. It is regrettable that, under pressure from the left, the reporter is ingemploying young people from 'migration backgrounds' into these target groups, which is Hungary typical problem in most Western European countries, but since it is Hungary non-immigrant country, it is not relevant for us to receive particular attention and support. The programme also offers young people in Hungary another opportunity to gain experience and acquire skills that can be used in the world of work.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – The European Solidarity Corps has been one of the best ideas of this legislature. It is an initiative that reinforces our core values and focuses on the future of Europe, which is young people. In times where the danger of selfish ideologies and nationalist temptations grows, we cannot pass up the opportunity to pool European solidarity and aim for a future of greater principled cooperation. Working together will enable us to develop a clearer awareness that, on a diverse continent, we face common challenges for all, such as environmental protection, immigrant integration, natural disaster prevention. This project is a success for the young people themselves, since its launch in 2016, more than 93,000 have been recorded throughout Europe. I am sure that taking part in any of your solidarity projects will contribute to your personal enrichment and enable you for better job insertion. For this reason, I am pleased that the initiative has a higher budget for the period 2021-2027, 1 260 million euros. Having participated in the improvement of the European Solidarity Corps is a great source of satisfaction for me.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Angelika Niebler, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on ENISA, the ‘EU Cybersecurity Agency’, and repealing Regulation (EU) 526/2013, and on Information and Communication Technology cybersecurity certification (‘Cybersecurity Act’) (COM(2017)0477 – C8—0310/2017 – 2017/0225(COD)) (A8—0264/2018), and – the report by Julia Reda, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Cybersecurity Industrial, Technology and Research Competence Centre and the Network of National Coordination Centres (COM(2018)0630 – C8-0404/2018 – 2018/0328(COD)) (A8-0084/2019).

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to begin by thanking all the rapporteurs from the political groups for their good cooperation or intensive cooperation in the trialogue with the Commission. From the refrigerator to the coffee maker to the pacemaker, from the energy networks to the telecommunications networks to the transport infrastructure – everything will be connected to everything in the future. What does this mean for us, ladies and gentlemen? For us, this means that cybersecurity must be one of the top political priorities in Europe. You may remember that two years ago we had wannaCry a major cyberattack. More than 200 000 IT systems across Europe have been affected, there has been anger in the United Kingdom, hospitals have been affected, in Germany the scoreboards of Deutsche Bahn have been suspended and some telecoms companies in Spain have been paralysed. So you can see what such a Europe-wide international cyberattack can have for dramatic consequences. I think we are well advised to prepare as Europeans for attacks of this kind. In view of what we have already achieved in recent years in terms of cybersecurity in Europe, particularly with the help of the European Parliament, I believe that we are quite well equipped. There is a European cybersecurity strategy, we adopted the Critical Infrastructure Directive a few years ago, we will adopt the Cyber Security Act tomorrow, and we will network competence centres in Europe and also build a European cyber competence centre. This is precisely the right answer to these international challenges. So what is the Cybersecurity Act about? Well, firstly, to strengthen our European cybersecurity agency ENISA. I am pleased that the Commission has made a bold proposal to increase this very enISA agency, both in terms of personnel and funding, and we here in Parliament wanted to give the European agency even more powers. This was also one of the critical points in the debate, in the discussion with the Member States. We want to have strong national cybersecurity competence centers. However, we in Parliament were particularly concerned about strengthening ENISA, our European cybersecurity agency, in other words, that it is not only involved in greater coordination between national security agencies, but also has independent competences, particularly in the area of certification. We want to create a European roll-out of certification frameworks in Europe. This is also a huge advantage for our domestic industry, if you do not just have certification in one country, but if the framework is given accordingly throughout Europe. It was important for us in Parliament that security levels be introduced for smart devices, for smart products, services and systems, and for us it was also important that in future there should be product information for consumers for these smart devices, for these smart devices. We think the consumer needs to know if their device is safe. We think that the consumer also needs to know how to safely adjust his device. All this is now in the proposal. We are happy that this was taken up in the trialogue. Personally, I would have liked to have gone one step further here. I would have imagined that it makes sense for critical infrastructures to also impose mandatory certification frameworks. I believe that we have now reached a good compromise. As a first step at ENISA, we will determine in which area it makes sense to make such certifications mandatory with a long-running annual programme. I also believe that this is a sensible next step. The next steps will follow. Cybersecurity is a mega-important issue, especially for us in the European Union. I am pleased that we have also been able to reach such a good compromise in rapid discussions with the Council and with the Commission as a Parliament. I hope that it will be adopted tomorrow by a large majority.

name: Julia REDA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, today we are also debating the proposal establishing the European Cybersecurity Industrial, Technology and Research Competence Centre, and establishing the Network of National Coordination Centres. By coordinating the implementation of the cybersecurity programmes from Digital Europe and Horizon Europe, the Centre will complement the work of the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) and increase the competitiveness of the European cybersecurity industry and research. With the Reda report we are acknowledging that cybersecurity is not a status that can be achieved by buying a certain product. Information and communications technology (ICT) evolves constantly and so do the threats. It requires constant efforts to make our infrastructure, communication and information systems more secure. Cybersecurity is a process that continues throughout the life cycle of a product, but the most secure product is not enough if we fail to secure the underlying infrastructure. The report welcomes as an advantage that businesses and expertise are distributed across Europe. We embrace the wealth of knowledge and potential of our unique ecosystem of small and medium—sized cybersecurity companies. In addition to this, we involve the broader cybersecurity community in Europe. This community ranges from researchers in academia to individual entrepreneurs, but we also want to connect to actors in consumer associations and include the crucial contribution of civil society initiatives, including those of ethical hackers. The proposal for a cybersecurity competence centre gives the unique opportunity to shape the future of cybersecurity in Europe. The fact that expertise is distributed across the Union is a strength, but also a challenge to connect them in projects. For those reasons we are encouraging collaborative approaches and investment in free and open-source software and open hardware. Businesses throughout Europe are struggling to fulfil their demand for skilled workers. In the ICT industry each unemployed worker is matched with approximately 1.5 open jobs. Clearly businesses cannot afford to ignore half of society in their search for potential. The report therefore wants to achieve a more balanced and diverse workforce in ICT and also in the governance structures of the Cybersecurity Competence Centre because it is good for business, and even more so, because it is in the interest of equality. In the past months and years there has been one debate gaining more and more public attention. It is the debate about the consequences that decisions taken by the digital industry have for society at large. We cannot ignore this debate in our cybersecurity research. The Cybersecurity Competence Centre needs to take into account what societal and ethical implications its projects may have and anticipate the concerns its actions may raise. We must not take a narrow view of cybersecurity research by only involving computer scientists. Instead, social scientists and ethicists must have a seat at the table. Thanks to the ambitious work of all colleagues involved, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) has found a solid and balanced report. We all agree on the European Union’s crucial task of promoting democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms worldwide. That is why we need to be very clear in respect of the Treaties when it comes to the funding of technology that can be used for military applications. Therefore, I would like to ask you to make it even clearer and to support my plenary amendments to underline that, when it comes to defence, the Centre’s role should be to facilitate the resilience—building initiatives against cybersecurity threats such as the protection of critical infrastructure. The Cybersecurity Competence Centre should have no role in developing and building cyber-weapons. There is no question that some of the technologies have applications beyond just the civilian sphere, for example, cryptography. Fortunately, we can rely and build upon the existing frameworks for the control of dual-use technology that this House has already helped create. I would like to thank all the colleagues and shadows for their good collaboration on this file.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, in an increasingly digitised and connected world, cybersecurity is today a real political priority. With the adoption of the European Cybersecurity Act, the Union is equipding itself with clear and harmonised measures to prevent cyber-attacks on the network. Strengthening ENISA's operational and coordination capabilities and creating a European certification scheme are the added value of this regulation. We would have been able to take an even more ambitious step, for example by introducing a compulsory certification mechanism for products whose use is intended for operators of critical services. That was not the way to do it. In any case, in the future, when users buy a tablet or mobile phone they will be able to check if it is certified and what its level of reliability is. However, this represents a considerable step forward in increasing confidence in the European market for related goods and services.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank the rapporteurs, both Angelika Niebler and Julia Reda, all the shadow rapporteurs and associated committees, for their constructive efforts to deal with these two critical legislative files as a matter of urgency.
