They will reinforce EU cybersecurity structures and improve our collective resilience to combat cyber-attacks in a mutually supportive and coordinated way, as part of building the digital single market. Firstly, on the Cybersecurity Act, the Commission fully supports the political agreement reached by the co-legislators. This agreement is the result of good cooperation between the co-legislators on the future of ENISA, the European Agency for Cybersecurity, and on setting up a cybersecurity certification framework for the digital single market. It will strengthen the regulation in several important areas. In particular, it puts in place a clear, open and robust EU framework for cybersecurity certification. The European Union will be able to agree certification schemes that are fit for purpose, keep our citizens safe and businesses resilient, and meet the needs of both the regulators and markets. It will provide ENISA with a permanent, stronger mandate to contribute to the cybersecurity of the EU. ENISA is already using its expertise in cybersecurity exercises to help prepare securing the upcoming European Parliament elections. Secondly, and equally importantly, I would like to strongly welcome the report on the cybersecurity competence centre and network of national coordination centres proposal. This proposal is a key element for building a secure European digital single market. It responds to the urgent need to build up our cybersecurity capabilities. It uses the excellent research carried out in Horizon 2020 and the future Horizon year. It is in Europe’s strategic interests to make sure that EU industries are at the cutting edge in developing next-generation cybersecurity and digital technologies. We have proposed the digital year programme to finance the development of new cybersecurity capabilities in Europe, and to invest with the Member States and the private sector in their deployment across the European Union. With a planned network of national coordination centres, we want to make sure that Member States bring together all relevant parties involved in developing new cybersecurity capabilities for the digital single market, the public and private sectors, as well as academia. I’m delighted that the European Parliament’s report shares our vision on the future of European cybersecurity and technologies and the importance of ensuring access to these financial means, based on priorities agreed between all relevant stakeholders. The Parliament has worked hard on this file in a very short time and I’m grateful for this. By strengthening Europe’s cybersecurity capabilities across the entire digital technology value chain, we are ensuring that the digital single market, that we have built together, will be strong and resilient to cyber-threats. I look forward to the discussion.

name: John HOWARTH
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, cyber attacks are not a temporary fashion, they are not something that is going to go away any time soon. They are about serious money and serious politics. The permanent mandate for the agency to counter them, the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA), is therefore not a luxury; it is absolutely essential. It is also a fact that, to paraphrase, the bad IT crowd needs to be combated with a better IT crowd, so the agency needs to have the resources to be able to attract the best people in the field. That said, the agency also needs to operate efficiently and it’s debatable whether two locations is a sensible way to go in the medium term. Nonetheless, we welcome the report and the notion of an EU-wide certification scheme. For cybercrime, borders have never been relevant and therefore combating cybercrime across borders is absolutely essential.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating a report and I hope that an extremely important report will be voted on tomorrow, because 80% of the citizens, the population of the Union, are connected to the internet and, ultimately, the lives of citizens, but also the economies of the Member States depend on technology, on digital technology. At the same time, there is this risk of cyber attacks. That is why I will support the report on the establishment of the European Industrial, Technological and Cybersecurity Research Skills Centre, as well as the networks of national and coordination centres, because, as the Commissioner said, it is very important that things work in the system, within the internal market. I am pleased that, on a proposal from the Commission, amendments have been added from colleagues in Parliament on SMEs. We know very clearly that they are more vulnerable than large companies because, of course, they are not specialised in cybersecurity. It is therefore necessary for the Skills Centre and the Security Skills Network to provide support to SMEs for access to knowledge and training.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Also on behalf of the LIBE Committee, I congratulate Mrs Niebler on the successful conclusion of the negotiations on the new ENISA mandate.  The new certification procedures are good and important, but they are unfortunately voluntary. Article 48a, which the LIBE Committee wanted to insert on this, would have been an important step in this area. For the first time, it would have introduced a mandatory minimum standard of IT security for all connected devices offered on the European market. We are always talking about greater security here in Parliament, and here we would have the opportunity to avoid security gaps that many citizens are not even aware of, because unsafe devices can very easily be hacked and then used to attack other devices or security-related infrastructure. A comparison: we do not issue type-approval for cars whose brakes or clutches are only tested voluntarily and for which there are no minimum standards.  Ladies and gentlemen, we MEPs have recognised the problem. It is not for nothing that we are discussing security aspects for our mobile networks this week. We only need to tackle it seriously – at the latest at the next revision of the ENISA regulation, or even before that in the Product Liability Directive or in the revision of the CE label. IT—Security is now a central part of our social security. Let us take the matter as seriously as is necessary.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank Angelika Niebler in this discussion, because it is quite simply a matter of creating trust systems. We want to be able to trust the Internet in our devices again, and we do not want protectionism, because there is, of course, a number one question in the world: safety for our citizens when using their devices. We do not want to get problems here from either the military or the civilian level. That is why, of course, Mr Niedermayer has made it clear that it is not just China, but that it should be our common concern worldwide to establish this cybersecurity; this is a crucial area. I would like to thank Mrs Reda for the Cyber Security Centres, because of course 28 Member States with joint coordination can achieve much more here. I would also like to thank Mrs Reda for putting forward the request for the trialogue tomorrow, because it is very important for us that this is achieved quickly – before the elections – for our citizens. We know that the NIS directive and the data protection directive must be implemented accordingly, and we naturally want to establish these centres accordingly close to training centres, at universities of applied sciences, and, above all, for our small and medium-sized enterprises, to provide access to security in the first place. In this respect, I believe that the Digital Fund, the Defence Fund and the Connecting Europe Facility and the Horizon Europe programme will be a great help.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, let me thank the colleagues with whom we worked together on the cybersecurity act, especially Mrs. Nibbler, Mr. Telichka, Mr. Danti. First, we have a double budget of the European Cybersecurity Agency, we have its permanent mandate and we have our own technical capabilities of THE ENISA, which I hope are only a first step in the right direction and the ERISA will yet have even more serious technical capabilities and the opportunity to help each Member State. I would also like to express, unlike the other rapporteurs, my satisfaction that there will be voluntary certification, as I have noticed the temptation to have mandatory certification to be used as a market advantage for some companies over others, and not so much as a concern for consumers. I would like to mark two controversial moments in the legislation on national competence centres. One is the text which currently states that only bodies established within the Union and natural persons residing within the Union can be accredited as members of that community, and that I mean does not entitles third-country subsidiaries that meet the criteria and have cybersecurity expertise. If we want to build cybersecurity, it cannot be built solely on the territory of the European Union. We have also given powers to the ESISA on research needs and similar powers are also given in regulation for competence centres. It is necessary to avoid advocating such powers, as there is a risk that we will create too much legislation and that it is not implemented or overlapped.  We currently have three excellent pieces of legislation to work on, namely the Cybersecurity Act, the Competence Centres Act and network information security. I believe that one of the first tasks of the ESISA should be to start working on the creation of a certification scheme for 5G equipment, which is, as you know, a popular topic lately.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It also seems to me that this certification is of great importance, even though, as my colleague mentioned here, it will be voluntary for the time being. However, the Commission has the possibility to review the effectiveness of this voluntary certification and to evaluate it after some time. But the importance of cybersecurity, as we know, is huge. This is indicated by the data. As you know, households around the world have about five billion internet-connected devices. Some predict that this number is expected to rise to fifteen billion by 2021. Manufacturers are introducing new devices, new models of goods that are connected to the Internet, while the installation of appropriate security measures does not go hand in hand. We know that a single-home hacking attack can already cause big problems for owners, but at the same time it is also the case that such an attack on multiple devices can also be used by cyber criminals as a tool to attack the strategic infrastructure of the state. Researchers at Princeton University conducted simulations that showed that a sudden 30 percent jump in electricity demand could effectively shut down all generators in the attacked area, so the safety of private homes is also linked to strategic security. For example, 90,000 internet-connected air conditioners or eight thousand water boilers are enough to take over, the researchers write. Therefore, we undoubtedly need better security, adequate security, both critical infrastructure and home use items.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I shall start by thanking my colleague Angelika Niebler especially, but also colleagues Peter Kouroumbashev and Nicola Danti, for the excellent cooperation during those late hours. I think I will not be revealing any secrets if I say that cyber-attacks and cybersecurity are very high on the list of concerns of our public. And rightly so: we are still vulnerable, and today we are vulnerable against attacks which can lead to the disclosure of data and other serious issues, but which are still manageable. Tomorrow – and I don’t even want to say it – we could see a serious threat that could concern our health, our security and our safety in broader terms. I believe that what we have managed to achieve with the Cybersecurity Act, as well as with strengthening ENISA, is the right response. Of course, we can always have a debate on whether it is sufficient or not. Well this is what was feasible on the day we were finalising negotiations with the Council. I need to say I would appreciate it if some Member States would understand better that we are as strong or as weak as the weakest part of the chain. I think that apart from the Cybersecurity Act and ENISA we need a change of mind-set, and that is why I would like to draw attention also to the latest statement by President Macron, also seconded yesterday by the leader of CDU/CSU, when talking about cybersecurity and also a European agency for the protection of democracies. Of course these are different issues but they are heading in the right direction. I think we have a basis on which we can build and I will hold President Macron to his word in future developments as we need to develop them a bit further.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As our societies become more digital, they are also becoming increasingly vulnerable. It is therefore gratifying that tomorrow we are voting to strengthen cybersecurity in Europe. Now we are increasing our resources to make our digital systems more robust.  With stricter certification rules, we can feel confident that our mobiles, computers and other digital products, which we use daily, meet the high security standards we set in Europe. With this legislation, we strengthen our digital resilience and have tools to address both current and future challenges in this area.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, cybersecurity has been a very topical concept over the last few years. In August 2017, the European Commission prepared its first package on this subject, which strengthens ENISA. The report under discussion aims to strengthen the network of national coordination centres. These competence centres will develop the relevant parts of the Digital Europe and Horizon Europa directives by allocating grants and support.  Competence centres are expected to coordinate and facilitate the work of the cybersecurity community-wide network. I support the rapporteur's interest in strengthening the security of free and open source software, as their vulnerability may compromise the functioning of the Internet and related services. Centres should promote the resilience and integrity of networks and information systems. It should not focus on dual and, where appropriate, military use technologies.  In accordance with the Treaties, this division must be respected. That is why this department is defined in the report and is a key issue for us to decide on the support of the report under discussion.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I thank the rapporteurs. This reform of the European Cyber Security Agency allows for the coordination of national authorities responsible for this issue and the sharing of information. It represents an effective response to cyber security problems at European level, while respecting the role of states in the areas of regal and national security. From the violation of our privacy to financial misappropriation, the lack of serious regulatory standards puts our digital environment under threat of cyberattacks. Like the Europe of nations we want, we must cooperate on cyber security. Beyond cooperation, voluntary certification will allow consumers to be better informed about the digital protection provided to the products they will buy, which is a big step. However, in the long run, only a mandatory certification will secure an internet of objects whose place in our societies is exponential. Finally, it should be noted that the massive digitization of our daily lives makes cybersecurity a major topic and that the growth of the budget devoted to it makes sense. Nevertheless, if we concede a 40% increase in ENISA's budget by 2022, let us remember that the European Union budget should be designed to be reduced in the context of Brexit.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, first of all, congratulations to my friend Angelika Niebler on her excellent work on this important piece of legislation. I think the agreement achieves what we want it to achieve, and will help protect us against cyber-attacks. A robust EU cybersecurity strategy is vital to enable us to repel any cyber-attacks against our energy supplies, aviation sector, commercial sectors or governments. Hackers are now targeting sensitive sectors for criminal and terrorist purposes, and this is a real concern. Thankfully, the work that has been done on this proposal, and the agreement reached will go a long way to ensuring that such concerns are addressed. We hear about data breaches, malware and online financial scams on a regular basis now, and about more and more sophisticated plots. We must be ready to defend crucial infrastructure, such as energy grids, plants and industry, against sinister attacks from criminals or terrorists. Shutting down electricity grids on a large scale for a prolonged time could cause massive disruption and economic damage. I welcome the strengthened role for the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA), and indeed my own country has the potential to be a cybersecurity hub for Europe. Ireland is world renowned as a high-tech country with a skilled workforce and it is already home to the largest, biggest tech companies. Companies like VMware in Cork can do an awful lot to prevent cyber-attacks. We have the expertise readily available to develop more cybersecurity services quickly and to become the global leader in securing personal and financial information online. I look forward to seeing the sector back home develop in the coming years. Finally, it was my privilege to be part of a European Parliament delegation to Silicon Valley last year, where we met all the top companies. Cooperation with those companies would be very helpful as well.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I had the pleasure of being the shadow rapporteur for the Centre of Excellence for Cybersecurity for my group, and I can say that we very much welcomed the Commission's proposal in this context. I am also very pleased with the position taken by the Committee on Industry. In this context, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation. In particular, my group, the S&D, was particularly important in ensuring coherence of existing structures such as the relevant enISA agency, and the decision of the Committee on Industry now contains wordings to ensure good cooperation. We have seen that the governance of this cybersecurity centre in relation to national entities works in such a way that the necessary expertise is used in all places, and we have ensured that, in the end, only European entities can be privileged by the programme. In the end, it was important to us that, if military cybersecurity projects are to be promoted, money can also be brought in from the European Defence Fund. In this way, we want to ensure that civilian programmes can only be used for civilian products. That is why we can fully support the text that is now before us. This has been incorporated into the position of the ITRE Committee. I am a little reluctant to go straight into trialogue negotiations. I have the impression that when it comes to the issues of financing, voting and so on, there will be insane differences with the position of the Council of Ministers. Time will show that. He is due to make a decision on Wednesday.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: Mr President, rapid digitisation is making cyber security increasingly important. Foreign telecom companies are gaining market share here. Research shows that our companies are inadequately equipped to deal with cyber risks and we need to be vigilant about the interference of other power blocs. That is why we are now coming up with the Cybersecurity Regulation, a European strategy with many measures that will invest in data security and cyber-attack protection. And we don't do it alone. We leave enough room for governments and companies to make agreements among themselves and to continue to work on innovation. We must now ensure that the necessary investments are made throughout Europe and that the measures are properly implemented in the interests of European consumers.  I call on the European Union to follow this up and recommend member states such as Belgium to take further measures themselves against, for example, the shortage of cyber security experts. Let's make Europe safe online.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: – Madam President, we are debating today a fundamental step in defining a European cybersecurity strategy that will aim at setting up state of the art capabilities in Europe. The new framework proposed by the Commission is a true answer to the need to coordinate Member States’ efforts in cooperation with the industrial sector to grant our citizens and customers an adequate supply of safe products and services without depending upon imported solutions from non-EU countries. Thanks to intense negotiations in committee, and the good cooperation achieved with the rapporteur, Julia Reda, and the shadows, we now have a solid and balanced text which ensures that the European Competence Centre will work as a coordinator to set priorities and avoid the duplication of initiatives in Member States in a good connection with ENISA’s new mandate under the Cybersecurity Act. Secondly, the Centre will award funding from the Digital Europe Programme and Horizon Europe, giving concrete support to research and innovation initiatives to help them to reach the market stage. Thirdly, it would be possible to respect Member States’ existing approaches to cybersecurity by allowing synergies between civilian and military applications, thus allowing the pooling of financial resources and avoiding overlaps of precious expertise. Last but not least, as a rapporteur for the Digital Europe Programme, I am very happy about the coherent and clear approach given to the governance structure of the Centre and its relationship, together with the national coordination centres, with the network of digital innovation hubs provided for under Digital Europe.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, more and more our lives are lived and shared online. That is why our personal data is now such a valuable asset that companies and governments want to collect, exploit or access it. That's also why there are so many criminals who want to rob them. Recent scandals such as Facebook and Cambridge Analytica are the most real demonstration of this. We need the means to deal with these threats, but we need to ensure that respect for human rights is the central axis of the actions of organisations to combat cybercrime. So we cannot ignore the essential role that people have to play in this struggle. We should not ignore that we need citizens to be empowered to make more informed decisions about their data, their management and how to keep them safe. We need entities like ENISA, but we also need all authorities and people who are aware of their role in this fight and never, but never, cross the line of human rights, however desirable the profits may be.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to begin by thanking our rapporteur, Angelika Niebler, for the excellent work on this dossier. I hope that the Committee on the Internal Market and Our Counterpart, Mr Danti, have been able to make a useful contribution to this.  Having already said a great deal about the structure of decision-making, I would simply like to remind you once again that the financial damage caused by extortion software worldwide in 2019 is expected to be more than USD 11.5 billion, and the human attack area is expected to be six billion people by 2022. These are ENISA figures which make it clear that the problem we are talking about is now far outweighing the European market and that we must therefore urgently establish uniform and common objectives on the part of the EU, which we must not leave to the Member States alone, even if this can also be an important part of national security in individual cases.  The European Union wants to invest 1.8 billion in cybersecurity by 2020. That is a good thing, but if we compare it with the United States of America, we have to say that there are around 22 billion. In other words, we are lagning a little behind here. That is why this directive, which we are adopting today, not only gives new powers to the European Union's Cybersecurity Agency and that we are strengthening Europe, but it must also mean that the Member States and the economy invest more in cybersecurity if we really want to face up to the danger that lies ahead.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, cybersecurity is today, as all the facts show, one of the key keys to ensuring the competitiveness of the European economy, protecting its citizens from the threats arising from new technologies used illegally and developing the processes of free choice and democratic representation. It therefore makes perfect sense to strengthen ENISA's capacity and potential by increasing the resilience of the European area against cyber-attacks and creating increased skills and capabilities for prevention, detection and response. But it is also essential to implement a system of certification of products and systems. Achieving this requires cooperation and coordination. National knowledge and development centres will be given a strong boost with Horizon Europe and Digital Europe. The certification network should take advantage of these skills and operate in a model of articulation capable of ensuring, in a distributed and aggregateform manner, the integrity and resilience of procedures and networks and the quality of information. It is not an easy challenge, but it is a priority that we have to fulfil to ensure the strategic autonomy of the European Union in the new Digital Society.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate you on the negotiation and the happy conclusion of the trilogue. This is the next important step after the NIS directive to strengthen cyber security in the European Union that protects both our economy and our society, but also our democracy. Every day we have cyberattacks, many of which come from third countries and our digital economy is evolving exponentially and these attacks will also evolve exponentially. It is therefore very important to strengthen the European Union in dealing with tools and policies, but not only in cooperation, but also in coordination between Member States and in the exchange of information, because cyber security is a moving objective. ENISA, therefore, based in Greece, is an important part of this effort. With the passage of the EU Cybersecurity Act it is greatly strengthened, acquires increased powers and is staffed with experts to deal with cyber-attacks. However, we must continue and substantially complete investments in cyber security, supporting innovation and through the European Union's financial instruments – we are investing around 2 billion for 2021-2027.  I believe that it is on the right track and I hope that the new regulation on security centres and networks, which we are also voting on, will also be completed and the trilogue will begin, so that with this composition of the European Parliament we can actually complete this strategic plan for cyber security. So I think we're achieving a lot today, we've got a little bit more to go. Having also completed the artificial intelligence bill, we understand that the threats are constantly increasing. Thank you very much and good luck.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President, as we know, the world is becoming more connected, increasingly digitised, and just as digital union is a challenge for the European Union, security in the European Union is also our common challenge. Our systems, from energy, transport, health, banking deposits, and ultimately elections, and ultimately individuals, are increasingly exposed. I, too, have been the target of identity theft lately, so I know very well what it means to you, what can happen to you as an individual or to the European Union as a whole. I very much support what we are enacting with this legislative package so that the European Union accedes with a unified, organised approach, because each country will certainly not be able to resist the cyber threat. In the autumn, I had the chance to be in Israel, which is even more exposed than Europe, and there I was able to see what a ten million country does, so I am very supportive of this comprehensive package, because the future of Europe also depends to a large extent on successful cybersecurity.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, information and telecommunications networks and systems have become pillars of economic growth. It is therefore of paramount importance to minimise the risks and threats to which our data is exposed by enabling consumers to have confidence in IT solutions.  The Cybersecurity Regulation will provide Europe with a long-term vision, strengthening the powers, competences and structure of the European Network Security Agency and introducing a cybersecurity certification system, so as to reduce the costly fragmentation of products and services in the single market.  On certification, I agree with the voluntary system, but for the basic and substantial guarantee levels; for products, processes or services that fall within the highest level of guarantee, it is more appropriate, on the other hand, to provide for a mandatory system. Manufacturers or suppliers of ICT products, processes and services must be obliged to provide structured certification information so that the consumer can have useful information when choosing the device.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we are talking about cybersecurity, the measures we need to take. But what measures, Commissioner, Mr Anship, will the European Union take against a Member State that monitors its citizens? Because a few days ago, on 4 March, we had preventive arrests in the city of Giannitsa, supporters, Greek citizens, who disagree with the despicable agreement of the Prespas. They were arrested as a precaution by the police and the Minister of Civil Protection, Mrs Gerovasilis, said that the government monitors social media, monitors Facebook, gathers information about citizens and makes preventive arrests and sends people to the courts, those fighters fighting against the sell-off of our Macedonia and our history. These are recorded.  So what measures are you going to take? Is it possible to have a violation of the law, a violation of gdpr regulation and to have a government that processes citizens' personal data and monitors the Internet and makes illegal preventive arrests? I want your opinion, Commissioner. Denounce this practice of deprivation of the democratic rights of Greek citizens.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will go back to the beginning of our term of office – five years ago in this House, a large part of us disregarded the issue of cybersecurity, and as it did not underestimate, it at least underestimated it. Hybrid conflicts, hybrid warfare, and terrorist threats have changed that optics. Today we are in a special situation, but I think in some sense good. We are strengthening our institution and strengthening this institution budgetaryly, strengthening it personally, but we are also strengthening it more compulsively, which is very important and very important and is worth appreciating. It is a pity that time – it is a pity that the world does not stand still. It is also constantly evolving in those threats that we have talked so much about today. However, it is worth supporting this report because it will be an important step in improving security in Europe, and I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members for the valuable debate and for your views expressed today. The Cybersecurity Act will create a flexible and market-oriented cybersecurity certification framework and give a permanent mandate to ENISA. This will make the digital single market stronger and more cyber-secure. As the digital single market grows and develops, Europeans should be fully aware of both the benefits and the risks involved. We have a collective responsibility to ensure that risks are properly addressed and that digital products and services are cyber-secure throughout their lifetime. The Cybersecurity Act is one of the building blocks for the EU’s cyber-resilience, along with the Network and Information Security Directive. The Cybersecurity Competence Centre and Network will be key to make sure that we have European capacities to protect the digital single market. Cybersecurity expertise centres located across EU countries should now have adequate resources facilitated by the European Cybersecurity Competence Centre. We now need to transform that expertise and experience into innovative cybersecurity products and services, and support their uptake across the economy. We must strengthen the European cybersecurity ecosystem, provide Europe with the means to autonomously secure its digital assets and to compete on the global technology markets. This requires coordinated work, both nationally and EU-wide, combining efforts from both the public and private sectors, so that we achieve significant progress. I am very grateful for the rapid pace of the legislative work on the Competence Centre and Network. By voting this week, and indicating your intention to conclude negotiations within this mandate, Parliament is giving a clear indication of the political importance of this file and the EU’s determination to meet the challenges that we face in cybersecurity today. The Commission is ready to assist the co-legislators in the upcoming negotiations.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Just a heartfelt thank you from my side for the very inspiring debate today. I am pleased that we agree on the importance that cybersecurity must also have in the European Union in the future. And I would simply like to thank you for the many positive feedback son era, which is the report. I believe that we in Parliament have done an excellent job. We wanted to strengthen Europe on this issue. I believe that we have succeeded in this with this Cyber Security Act, which will be adopted tomorrow. In this respect, I am very, very happy today that this step can be completed so successfully. For me, it is simply important to underline once again that we have a unique opportunity here to set a standard internationally. So that was always important for us. With the General Data Protection Regulation, we have already had the opportunity internationally, or we have succeeded in setting a standard here, and if we now manage to be international trendsetters in the area of cybersecurity for products, for services, for systems and for the whole ecosystem, then this is a great matter for our European Union. I thank all those who have helped. We consulted quickly, but I do not think we discussed superficially, but really pushed for a good solution. I would stress that some colleagues thought that we should have been a little more ambitious. I share this view. I would have gone further with the mandatory certification, especially for the critical infrastructures. But there is always a next step after a successful first. In this sense: A heartfelt thank you to all those who have worked on this. I hope that this Cyber Security Act will soon be implemented in the Member States and that we will be making it more secure for our citizens in Europe and for all products.

name: Julia REDA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, as you can see from the debate, there is broad consensus in Parliament about the substance of the Cybersecurity Centre, but you will also have heard that there are different opinions about entering into negotiations. I would like to outline my approach on this. First of all, in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) we have already managed to make it very clear that civil funding cannot be spent on defensive applications, but I think, in order to have a strong position, it’s also really important to make sure that we do not fund activities that could actually undermine civil cybersecurity, such as back doors or hack—backs and other rather offensive applications. I hope that this is a consensus that will be achieved in the vote on Wednesday. If this is the case, I would not stand in the way of starting negotiations in order to see whether it’s possible to conclude with a political agreement within this mandate. However, there are, of course, political differences that remain. We will have to see exactly what the Council position will be and we will not seek an agreement at any cost. Because of the broad support that Parliament has in the changes that it has made to the Commission proposal, we would also require great flexibility from the Council and Commission to be able to conclude with a political agreement. So it will all depend on whether we can find this consensual approach but, if this is the case, I am confident that an agreement within this term is possible.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Let me only express my satisfaction that I have at least partially had the chance to listen to this debate, because I have the honour of leading the Security Working Group in the European Parliament, and I would like to thank Commissioner King for his cooperation so far.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – This Regulation is an important part and instrument of the European Union's new cybersecurity strategy, which aims to give Europe a long-term perspective on cybersecurity and to ensure confidence in digital technologies. The EU has already created a European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA) and adopted a Network and Information Security Directive (NIS Directive), which is currently being implemented by Member States. The "Cybersecurity Act" consists of two parts: the first part details the role and mandate of ENISA in order to strengthen the Agency. The second part introduces a European cybersecurity certification system in the form of a voluntary framework to improve the security of connected devices and digital products and services. ENISA must play an essential role in defining European cybersecurity systems, together with Member States and relevant stakeholders. As far as certification is concerned, the scope of the proposal should be clarified according to ITRE. On the one hand, not only products and services should be covered by this regulation, but the entire life cycle. Processes must therefore also be included in the scope of the regulation. On the other hand, certain areas of competence of the Member States should be clearly excluded, namely public security, national defence and the area of criminal law.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – We work for a Europe that protects its citizens and businesses. Cybersecurity is not an abstract topic, it affects 80% of companies in the EU. It also affects consumers – a 2017 Eurobarometer survey found that 87% of Europeans consider cybercrime "an important challenge for the EU's internal security".  Attacks like WannaCry affect hundreds of thousands of systems at once and prove that cybercrimes do not respect borders. This is why the EU needs to be more effective in the fight against cyber attacks, cyberespionage and cyber sabotage. It is important to increase our capacity to provide better protection for European citizens, businesses and public institutions.  The EU Cybersecurity Act is a key tool for a more secure Europe, strengthening the role of the European cyber agency ENISA and the Member States in developing cyber incident prevention, detection and response capabilities. A more secure and sustainable cyber infrastructure in the EU will increase citizens' confidence in the digital economy and unleash the potential of new technologies, leading us forward towards a more competitive and innovative Europe.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Paolo De Castro, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on unfair commercial practices in business-to-business relations in the food supply chain (COM(2018) )0173 – C8-0139/2018 – 2018/0082(COD)) (A8-0309/2018).

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has taken almost 10 years of debate, twenty countries have had to legislate on this issue, and above all we have needed the insistence of this Parliament and our two resolutions, the last of which - for which I thank Vice-President Mairead McGuinness once again - was adopted by an overwhelming majority in June 2016: it took all this to arrive today at the final vote on the directive against unfair commercial practices in the agri-food sector. It is an extraordinary achievement, made possible thanks to the protagonism and ambition of this Parliament. This ambition has resulted in crucial improvements compared to the initial proposal. To name but a few: the extension of the scope, which now protects 100 % of farmers and more than 95 % of the Union's agri-food holdings, with the increase from EUR 50 million to EUR 350 million in turnover; the inclusion of buyers based outside the Union among those who will have to comply with the Directive; the inclusion of all agricultural and not only food products, protecting strategic sectors such as floro-nursery and feed, feed for pets; the strengthening and doubling of prohibited practices, from 8 to 16, including, for example, late payment for non-perishable products, refusal to grant written contracts, or the threat of commercial retaliation in the event of a complaint; the better safeguarding of the confidentiality of the complainant's identity, in order to overcome the fear factor that all too often obliges our producers to accept these practices, with the right of complaint extended to all associations; the obligation to act and to put an end to unfair practices for national law enforcement authorities, to which we have also guaranteed greater powers both in the investigative phase and in terms of sanctions; not forgetting the enhanced cooperation between the various national authorities, which will have to meet at least once a year and exchange information and good practices in order to ensure the most uniform and ambitious application of the directive possible. It is worth remembering that this is in fact a question of minimum harmonisation, and that The Member States will be able to provide in their national legislation both for the extension of the parties involved and for the list of unfair practices to be banned. In order to achieve this result, ladies and gentlemen, in just eleven months from the publication of the Commission's proposal to date, despite the various attempts to block this directive once again, it has taken a strong political will on the part of all. That is why I would like to thank all those who have made this possible, starting, of course, with my colleagues in the Commission, starting with Commissioner Hogan, whom I thank, the shadow rapporteurs, the entire European Parliament negotiating team, the services, the Austrian Presidency, Minister Elisabeth Kostinger, President-in-Office of the Council, not forgetting the fundamental work done by all the technical groups and, of course, also by my team.   Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this directive is a Europe that shows that it can stand shoulder to shoulder with the weakest economic operators, such as farmers, and with all citizens. A supply chain characterized by unfair behaviour and therefore by an inefficient distribution of resources puts pressure on all producers, in a race to the bottom of prices that depresses both the quality of the products that arrive on the tables of families and citizens, and the quality of the production process, encouraging labour exploitation and unsustainable production practices. On the contrary, by overcoming these distortions within the agri-food chain, the directive will be a point of reference for achieving more transparent and fair markets, more efficient markets capable of generating benefits for society as a whole, and especially for consumers.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Mr President, Commissioner, this directive is undoubtedly one of the great advances of this Parliament. Indeed, it was our duty to combat the imbalance between small producers in the highly concentrated agri-food and distribution sectors. This pressure on prices from the markets is one of the causes of the current suffering of the agricultural world, while European food must be a top priority. This long-awaited directive abolishes unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, while enhancing transparency and combating the blackmail of multinationals. In this regard, I would like to warmly welcome the excellent work of my colleague and friend Paolo De Castro, with whom we worked together in a very tight time to ensure that this text, which is so important to our farmers, is finalised before the end of this mandate. Finally, I insist that all Member States go even further in their national legislation in order to eradicate, once and for all, these extremely harmful unfair practices, both for farmers and for food SMEs, but also for European consumers.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate and this week’s vote are very important, as Mr De Castro has said, not alone for what they represent but for what they will deliver. What this debate and the vote represent is an acknowledgment that, for far too long, the farmer and other smaller operators in our food supply chain have been disadvantaged by their relative weakness; but, more importantly, what this debate and the vote will deliver is protection for these farmers and suppliers of agri-food products further downstream. Many Members of this House have been consistent and vocal in calling for greater protection for the position of farmers in the agri-food supply chain – and rightly so. Without that influence, I have no doubt in saying, today might never have happened. I am pleased therefore that the Commission – and, of course, a very good Commissioner for Agriculture – could finally, and for the first time, response positively with a legislative proposal to ban certain unfair trading practices. Before reflecting briefly on the contents of the directive on which you are about to vote, I want to congratulate the rapporteurs for Parliament and the Austrian Council Presidency for their efforts in reaching these landmark achievements – particularly Mr De Castro, for Parliament, and Ms Köstinger and the Austrian team on behalf of the Council. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all the other committee people who have been involved: Mr Tarabella, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection; Ms McAvan on behalf of the Committee on Development; and Ms Pilar Ayuso on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection. I would include, as well, the shadow rapporteurs, Ms McGuinness and Ms McIntyre, and Maria Heubuch, Elsi Katainen, Matt Carthy, Marco Zullo and Jacques Colombier. All of you have played a remarkable part in ensuring that we are discussing this milestone legislation here this evening. It’s worth recalling, as Mr De Castro has done, that only eight months passed between the adoption of the Commission’s proposal in April and the conclusion of the political agreement in December, so it demonstrates very clearly that if there is the political will a lot can happen in almost all respects in this House. It will now be up to the Member States to transpose the directive, and I want to assure you that the Commission will follow this process carefully and closely and I trust that this House will do so as well. The final agreement is one that safeguards our initial objectives and our rationale behind the legislation, which is to protect the weak from possible abuses of buyer power by the strong. For the first time, rules will be introduced at a European level that target unfair trading practices and provide protection for all EU farmers, as well as most agri-food businesses, against practices that are contrary to good faith and fair dealing. The directive will introduce a minimum EU level of protection against unfair trading practices that occur in the food supply chain. That level will apply in all the Member States – which will remain free to go further, subject to internal market rules. For the first time, there will be a ban on 16 unfair trading practices which are imposed unilaterally by one trading partner on another. Other practices will be permitted only if they are subject to a clear and unambiguous upfront agreement between the parties involved. The agreement that we reached in December will apply to anyone involved in the food supply chain with a turnover of EUR 350 million, with differentiated levels of protection provided below that threshold. It is important to see this directive as part of a wider initiative to strengthen the position of farmers in the food supply chain. Indeed, the Agricultural Markets Task Force, under former Minister for Agriculture Cees Veerman, called for a better legal framework on producer cooperation, as well as improved market transparency. I am pleased to be able to tell the House, and to be able to report to you, that we have also achieved significant progress in these two areas through the Omnibus Regulation, in which Parliament was instrumental, including with the involvement of Mr De Castro and Mr Dess, and through the development of our market observatories. As you are aware, the Commission is working too on a proposal to extend our transparency initiative to cover the processing and retail sector end of the food supply chain and I expect to be in a position very shortly to announce more details of this initiative. Together, these three policy adaptations will allow farmers to seize greater opportunities as they present themselves in a market-orientated environment, and to defend themselves against market failures. In conclusion, can I reiterate my appreciation to all the Members of the House, to the rapporteurs in particular, and to the Austrian Presidency, which has shown very strong support for this initiative that will protect not only the interests but in some cases the very survival of our farmers, as Mr Tarabella has said. Nobody in the food chain has anything to fear from this legislation if they are behaving fairly.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, Commissioner, within the food chain farmers are undoubtedly the weakest link and we had to protect it. If we want sufficient agriculture and self-sufficiency of food for the European Union, we had no choice but to protect farmers because, just as distribution is highly concentrated, agricultural production is highly atomised and needed support.  I would therefore first of all like to congratulate the Commission on having made this proposal, as well as the Council and Mr Paolo De Castro, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs who have been able to carry it forward.  Even though the European Parliament's position was much stricter than we finally achieved, I think we are going to reach a very good agreement for farmers and for agriculture in general. In Spain we have a law of the food chain and I can assure you that it works very well.  It is true that some objectives have not been achieved— such as the inclusion of loss sales within prohibited practices—but others that you yourself have mentioned and which are very important.  I therefore have nothing left to congratulate Parliament, congratulate myself and congratulate us all, because this was an important necessity and today we are finally going to answer it.  Many years ago, Mrs McGuinness led a working group which, in the end, has paid off.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that it is very true that the pleas of the farming community through the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) did not fall on deaf ears because we have been looking for this for some time. You, as Commissioner, took it seriously and came forward with a proposal. So thank you for that. I think it is very significant. Of course, it will be tested in the Member States. I do welcome your comments that you will keep a close eye on implementation, because I see already in some Member States a hesitancy, questioning how it will be done. It’s got to be done without too much bureaucracy, and it’s got to be effective so that those with a genuine complaint can come forward and get results. But for me today is much bigger than the sum total of those unfair trading practices that will be banned. This is about the sustainability of the food-supply chain and we hear a great deal about that – about the challenge of climate, biodiversity, air quality and water quality. I think Mr De Castro was very right when he said that the current system operates in a very incorrect way. It results in a race to the bottom because farmers’ margins are constantly being tightened. So I very much welcome this as a first step towards a more sustainable food-supply chain. I read comments from Arla, who talk about their drive for more sustainable farming, where they say that consumers are willing to reward the most sustainable dairy farmers. I hope that is the case and that those who are dealing between consumers and farmers ensure that the farmers get a sustainable price for the work that they do. I had Irish dairy representatives over last week in Brussels and we spoke about issues around welfare and environment, and the challenges generally. They pleaded, because they said that the farmer is not getting rewarded sufficiently to deliver on all of those things. So tonight is a first step. Thank you, Commissioner. Thank you to the colleagues who listened when others would not. Together, I think we’ll make a difference.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with the directive on unfair commercial practices in business relations in the food chain, we are finally achieveing, and I congratulate the rapporteur, Paolo De Castro, on the great work he has done, so much so that the agreement reached in the trialogue considerably improves the protection of farmers and small and medium-sized agri-food enterprises. The number of unfair practices is increasing significantly, with eight more practices than the Commission's proposal, ranging from last-minute cancellation of orders to late payments, unilateral changes to contract changes to non-payments to suppliers for unsold goods by large purchasing power plants. One of the strengths is undoubtedly the anonymous complaint in defence of the confidentiality of the supplier during the investigative procedure not only with regard to his identity, but also with regard to all other information that the supplier himself identifies as sensitive. The rules contained in the directive finally restore dignity to the European agricultural world, strengthening the position of producers vis-à-vis large-scale distribution.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, for far too long, farmers and growers have been in the most precarious position in the food supply chain. For far too long, large retailers across the EU have been able to abuse their powerful position. This directive on unfair trading practices used as one of its bases the UK’s grocery supply code of practice. This is a legally binding code. The UK found that purely voluntary systems didn’t work. Voluntary codes didn’t change buyers’ behaviour, and that is why legislation is needed. I would like to thank our rapporteur Paolo De Castro and my fellow shadows, and Commissioner Hogan, for all the work they have put into this directive to deliver fairer treatment for our farmers. At Parliament’s insistence, the directive now includes all agricultural produce not just food. So that means that cut flowers, which are just as perishable as fruit and veg, are covered. We also extended the threshold so that suppliers with a turnover of up to EUR 350 million will be protected. That means all EU farmers are covered, and all producer organisations in the UK are covered too. I am also glad that the directive covers suppliers who are outside the EU, so not only will farmers in Kenya and Peru be protected, but in a post-Brexit world, UK farmers and growers will continue to be protected while selling into the EU. This is good news for farmers and consumers across the EU and beyond, and I am delighted to support it.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank The Agriculture Commissioner, Mr Hogan, the rapporteur, Mr De Castro, and the negotiators from all the groups for their excellent cooperation in completing this important directive within the deadline. We will have a truly balanced legislative text for the vote, which proves that when there is political will, it will be difficult to move forward even in a short space of time, even though, on the other hand, the background is long. Producers with profitability problems will be given concrete confirmation of their position on the food market by the directive. This is an important message from the EU – precisely for producers who are increasingly required and who have been subjected to regrettable cuts. As a farmer myself, I know that the result is wanted on the market rather than on aid. I have often been asked what this directive means in concrete terms for the farmer. There are three things that could be summed up. Firstly, producers can also complain to the domestic supervisory authority about the activities of buyers located in other countries. This significantly lowers the threshold for food exports. Secondly, the directive creates a strong guiding effect, because sanctions will follow if the rules are not complied with. And perhaps most importantly, the directive also gives a strong back seat to national parliaments to make their own legislation, which can really be even tougher than this directive. I very much hope that this will have the full support and support of this House.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the It is really very good that the EU is now adopting a single regulation to limit the power of supermarket chains over food producers. I would also like to thank Paolo de Castro and all those involved for the really good cooperation. It is important to me that Europe does not stop here, because not all the problems have been solved by a long way. Farmers, but also the workers in the fields, in the greenhouses, the workers in the slaughterhouses and the small food processors are under pressure from different sides, not only from the side of the supermarket chains, but also from the side of the upstream sector – if I think only of the seed, fertilizer, feed or pesticide industries. And it is precisely in all these industries that we are seeing an increasing concentration of power. The merger of Bayer and Monsanto is just the latest example. In order for farms to be able to generate a fair income through their work, this concentration of power must be combated, both in the upstream and in the downstream sectors, and this can only be done by reforming competition law. Commissioner Hogan, would you be prepared to look into competition law as well? Would you ensure that future mergers take into account the effects on the environment, climate and health, but also on farm income? That was not the case with the deal with Monsanto and Bayer. I believe that Europe needs an ambitious project here, and we could move forward ambitiously together.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the situation whereby those who do the greatest amount of work in producing the food we eat receive the least amount of the profits has been getting worse every single year. Retailers and processors have been exploiting their position, while our farmers are expected to work on ever-tightening profit margins and often at a loss. Many of us had hoped that the EU would step up to the mark and that we would be able to deliver legislation on unfair trading practices (UTPs) that would rebalance the scales, recognise the importance of our farming communities and stand up to the corporate giants. This was the opportunity to do so: unfortunately that opportunity has been wasted. I cannot support this proposal because I cannot look farmers in the eye and tell them that their situation will improve as a result of its enactment. The failure to include a ban on below-cost selling of foodstuffs is just the most glaring of the deficiencies in the proposed legislation. One-third of the UTPs banned can continue if supermarkets manage to insert them into contracts. I hope that I’m proved wrong, that the implementation of this legislation will prove a game changer for our family farmers. I fear, though, that it will not, and that either we will have to return to this work or we will continue to see more farmers leave the land and our rural communities suffer for want of ambition and vision at EU level.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur for his good work. The adoption of the unfair commercial practices directive is a great achievement, so that we can finally have a fairer redistribution of economic value in the agri-food chain, so as to guarantee a better income for small farms, but also a better quality of products available for sale. This directive is a necessary act to restore balance in the commercial chain, providing protection for those who, because of their small size, are all too often at risk of being crushed by the abuses of larger players. The lack of bargaining power obliges many small businesses to sell their products under unfair terms, by suffering economic agreements that impoverish and by taking on the costs and risks of companies of others. Thanks now to clear rules at European level, all those commercial practices put in place by unscrupulous economic actors that end up crushing small and honest farmers are unequivocally condemned. Once and for all, unfair commercial practices such as unilateral and retroactive changes to supply contracts, commercial retaliation and payment for un rendered services will be stopped and punished.  We are handing over an important and effective instrument to the Member States. If these rules are properly applied, they will restore fairness and dignity to small businesses, that is to say to the weakest links in the agri-food chain.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I wondered if the reason you’re a little late for the debate was because Theresa May is in town and she was twisting your arm to persuade you to support Ireland leaving the European Union, which would solve the problem of having an EU border on the island of Ireland, but maybe that’s too much to hope for. You might also be wondering, with 18 days to go to Brexit, why a British MEP is actually bothering to talk here, but I honestly think that this flag will be in this Parliament in a year’s time. I really do believe that, and so for that reason, I want to say something about this report. I’m quite happy with the sentiment of it, but what worries me is that we have in Britain somebody called the Groceries Code Adjudicator. Her name is Christine Tacon and she is doing the work that you are talking about. Now, what I’m worried about is that she is going to be undermined by this legislation. Supermarkets will say to her, ‘ah yes Ms Tacon, but the EU rule says XYZ’, and they will then go to the European Court of Justice to undermine what she’s doing. Various staff of yours have assured me that this won’t happen, but over the last 30 years, the Commission has had a horrible way of always putting its legislation ahead of the British legislation. Please prove to me that I’m going to be wrong, but I would far rather have the status quo in Britain as we have it. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: blue-card question. – Mr Agnew knows I am easily provoked, so well done. Don’t worry about Ms Tacon: she’s a strong woman and well able to deal with this legislation. You said that you’re likely to be back with your flag in this Parliament and you said it almost with joy, which leaves me wondering: would you miss us if you have to go? We’re not pleading with you to stay, but maybe you have a soft spot for us after all. This is incredible news. Please clarify.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card answer. – Right, Mairead, I’m quite happy to clarify. What’s amusing me and making me laugh is the total incompetence of our politicians: nearly three years after a vote of the British people to leave this place, they still haven’t managed to do it. That is what causes me some amusement. Now, you raised another point, didn’t you? I’m just trying to recall what it was. Oh yes, that she’s a strong woman. I’m not talking about Theresa May; I’m talking about Christine Tacon. Yes, she is, and she shouldn’t be undermined by this place, and that is what’s worrying me.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Polish thinker, Stefan Kisielewski, once said that socialism is such a system in which problems unknown in any other system are heroally combated. And this discussion is a perfect example of this. This is the case: first, it starts with the fact that the clawed governments are trying to collect as much tax as possible and therefore collect commissions from all economic traffic on their territory, and therefore burden everyone with the obligation to record all this movement, because they want to know how much they can squeeze out of all. As a result, additional costs arise, difficulties in the activity. This centralizes the market, eliminates smaller sellers, introduces additional regulations that centralize the market, because centralization is at the hand of the government, because it is easier to control it. The result is, finally, a ban on retail sales to farmers, a weakening of their negotiating position, resulting in unfavourable contracts and low purchase prices. The result is not, as in our case, a withdrawal from these stupid regulations, but subsequent regulations, so next time we will meet to wonder why agricultural prices have gone up. I'm looking forward to it.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I invite my colleague from the country to discuss. Maybe he'll explain a lot of problems. Dear! After many years of work by the Committee on Agriculture, we can finally announce that we have a European legal framework to combat unfair practices in the food supply chain. I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan for his proposal for a directive and the rapporteur Paolo De Castro, shadow rapporteurs, for their work, which has allowed an exceptionally smooth agreement to be reached and adopted later in this term. It is also impossible not to mention Mrs McGuinness, who three years ago prepared an opinion for our committee, which was subsequently supported by a plenum. Thank you to many, many others.  I would like to point out one of the reasons for the poor position of the farmer in the food chain, which is the high fragmentation of agricultural producers. It is estimated that only less than 10% of farms have the opportunity to compete with the economic size of the market. This is why it is so important to improve market power that agricultural producers merge through producer organisations and cooperatives. The large number of small farms does not facilitate the creation of structured economic structures, such as producer groups.  I want to raise the need for economic dialogue between the actors in the food chain. It seems that representatives of the agricultural, processing and trade sectors are more likely to talk through the media than directly. I think that this task should lie with the European Commission and also with Parliament.  Finally, this directive is a major compromise that Commissioner Hogan has reached in the European Commission. Compromises, like these compromises, do not always solve many problems. We have a good start. Finally, there are possibilities for national legislation that can go further and solve many problems. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Resolutions have been voted on many times here in this Parliament, which state that the maintenance of small family farms is our priority here. You have just said that the fragmentation of farms is causing farmers to be weak. Rightly. So how do you vote when Parliament adopts such nonsense that it wants to maintain this inefficient structure of small agriculture?

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Yes, I have been dealing with the problem quite deeply and for a long time. I was the author of a report on small farms. Small farms need to be supported. They have their value. At the same time, the concentration process is progressing, which greatly improves, gives more opportunities for larger entities that have more production to merge. This may have a greater impact on the commodity market than highly fragmented farms. This is a process that goes on and small farms need to be supported, but it also needs to be socially supported and the development of commodity production must be supported.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, as you have all said, we are in congratulations. It's a great initiative. I would like to congratulate my colleague, Paolo De Castro, on all the shadow rapporteurs, from the Committees on Agriculture, the Internal Market and Consumer Protection or the Environment, and I would particularly like to congratulate Commissioner Hoogan because, after ten years, a few more, for the first time a Commissioner for Agriculture dares and takes forward in the College of Commissioners a directive of this wording. Others haven't been able to. Therefore, it has a value that is fair to recognize.  We've had a great fallacy. The big fallacy is that the chain was fine because prices had to be contained for consumers. That's. The chain is distorted, there are unfair trade practices that need to be corrected, and therefore the weakest must be protected. This is going to be done like this. And you know, Commissioner, My colleague Paolo, today we must send a message to all: 'Europe is on the side of farmers and consumers'. So far it hasn't been possible. So, out that fallacy of other sectors and let's get to work. This is the beginning. We must continue to make progress on European legislation, but it is a great start.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, my congratulations as well. I wouldn’t have expected anything less of Paolo De Castro than the report he has brought forward, but I also congratulate all involved on the remarkable speed with which this agreement was reached. The dominant bargaining power of large operators in the food supply chain has left farmers squeezed between the processors and the large multiples. Unfair trading practices have been a continuous problem for farmers across Europe and it is sensible to introduce extra protection for farmers. I am pleased this will be done in conjunction with already existing frameworks in Member States. For too long, we have seen – and continue to see – power concentrated in the hands of the buyers. This has resulted in an uneven playing field whereby farmers have had little influence to exert in the marketplace and been subject to unfair practices to cut their margins when you look at the fact that across Europe, farmers receive an average of 21% of the final price of the agricultural product. The various measures in this directive, such as banning late payments for perishable goods and banning late cancellations, will go a long way to restoring the imbalances, give farmers extra protection and keep food at the highest standards and quality. But we must not – and I give this warning – become complacent that our work here is done. One of the greatest obstacles to successful European legislation lies within incorrect implementation at Member State level – not at Brussels, at Member State level –and this is where we have got to follow it through. The key is implementation and monitoring what has been done. To those who actually say it should be more, people are always looking for more, but you have to crawl before you walk. At least we’ve done it. At least we’ve followed it through. Congratulations to all involved.

name: Giancarlo SCOTTÀ
text: Mr President, Mr De Castro, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the directive on unfair commercial practices in the food subsidiary is a first step that is not enough towards recognising a fact: the EU has built an internal market full of imbalances, starting with the one between mainly agricultural suppliers and commercial buyers. In this way, we seek to mitigate unfair behaviour between those in a de facto dominant position and suppliers, who often remain outside the sales mechanisms, witnesses of downward auctions and promotional clashes, who are often illegally asked to pay for some of the measures for the sale and storage of their products.  Today, in Italy, we share with apprehension the fate of the Sardinian sheep and goat livestock sector, committed not only to revolutionizing its aggregate model and making more efficient the mechanisms that regulate the Pecorino Romano PDO, but also to defend itself against some unfair behavior of some buyer who tries, also through a transfer price too low compared to production costs , to maintain a sidereal distance with farmers on the distribution of the final value. We therefore wholeheartedly support this measure, in the hope that, from the next parliamentary term, we will be concerned with giving new rules to the internal market, so that agricultural products can be given the right value throughout Europe, respecting different realities and different production costs.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear Paolo, how far we have come! Serving the essential objective of rebalancing relations within the supply chain and strengthening the position of farmers was our will. In the last two years, we have introduced three texts: the reform of competition law and its application to agricultural markets, the revision of the rules of contracting, with the establishment of an individual right to a written contract, and the establishment of a European framework to combat unfair trade practices. Yes, I think we can turn to the farmers with our heads held high. While these issues had been blocked for years, Parliament played an indispensable role in this fight against the timidities and divisions of the Council. In the future, it must continue to address these essential issues. We would not have been able to do this without the task force on agricultural markets at the heart of the milk crisis in 2016, and we must thank you for that, Commissioner. The conclusions of this working group have been essential to the progress we have made and are still making this evening. One last key topic remains on the table, that of market transparency. The committee is working on this and we will be making concrete proposals in the coming weeks as part of the CAP reform. Once again, Commissioner, we will need your support to complete this work on a cause that seems to you and to us to be a noble cause. We thank you for that.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, 350 euros a month: this is the income of one in three farmers in France. Every week, 260 farms disappear. Meanwhile, the profits and profits of the agri-food giants are increasing, while their shareholders are paying themselves more and more dividends. This situation is unequal and unfair. We all need to make a living from their work, and we all know this way. It was imperative to intervene. Let me thank Paolo De Castro, the shadow rapporteurs and you, Commissioner, for allowing this directive to succeed today. Indeed, justice and equality are needed. It will also be necessary to develop, as mentioned above, transparency, but also to implement, as you said, Commissioner, an observatory in all sectors of activity. Beyond this success, we will have to monitor the implementation of this directive and commit all Member States to go further than the only text that will be voted on tomorrow.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Thank you, Mr President. Late payments or unilateral contract modification: these are some of the practices that producers face on a daily basis. This week we are voting on legislation against unfair trade practices, an important step. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the Commissioner, for their part. The most essential part, as far as I am concerned, is that, in the first part, producers can lodge a complaint confidentially. Member States are now in the t look to implement this properly and thoroughly and to appoint an arbitrator in the food supply chain.
