I sincerely hope that every Member State will soon have a food referee who is independent, visible and approachable, with clout. Someone who builds a relationship of trust with the sector and who, if necessary, sits down at the kitchen table to hear what is really going on.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Mr President, this report on unfair trade practices in relations within the food chain is back to the plenary, I would say. It has therefore taken almost a year, since the publication of the legislative proposal, for the text to be put to a vote in our Assembly. His reference to a trilogue last October, although it further lengthened the time it took to adopt the report, still improved the economic security of our producers. Indeed, the number of practices considered unfair has been revised upwards, buyers from third countries have been added to the scope of the directive, producer organisations and inter-professionals will be able to lodge complaints on behalf of producers, the identity of the complaining producers will be protected, in order to avoid any form of pressure on them , and finally, the competent court will be chosen by the complainant. These improvements will, we hope, allow for better protection of our agricultural sectors from the agri-food giants. That is why we supported this report in the Committee on Agriculture and we will support it again this week in plenary. However, the work remains considerable before a real strengthening of the place of farmers in the food chain. We must not regard this text as the silver bullet and ignore this subject in discussions on the future CAP. Despite the efforts of some countries, such as France, on this issue, we can only see that the influence of producers in trade relations remains hopelessly weak. Producers expect results from us on this issue, which has a strong impact on the economy of our sectors. Let us therefore respond to their concerns, because they are urgent.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: –Mr President, let me, first of all, welcome the concerns of Commissioner Phil Hogan, but also of the two rapporteurs and of all colleagues, to closely follow the protection of European farmers, agricultural organisations and small and medium-sized enterprises in the face of unfair and often abusive behaviour by large operators in the supply chain. Unfair competitive practices take place throughout the food supply chain and also extend in connection with the marketing of other products. Small producers are frequent victims of abusive commercial behaviour involving late payments, cancellations and unilateral or retroactive changes to contracts. Expanding the scope by including all operators in the supply chain, as well as expanding categories of unfair practices, will lead to greater protection for farmers and consumers will have the guarantee of quality and affordable food. Acquired legal certainty will lead to the maintenance of price stability and, by implication, to the strengthening of the agricultural sector, and the interests of more than 11 million farmers and 300 000 processors in the European Union will be further and better defended. At the same time, I am certain that this proposal will further convince Romanian producers of the need for an association in strong organisations. By regulating a 4-year review clause, it will ensure that the provisions of the legislative text are assessed during the implementation process and that the Directive's measures are applied coherently in subsidiary legislation in the Member States.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the big supermarket chains are, through their power to negotiate prices and through unfair trade practices, the shortest and most acute problem in the entire food chain, which we need to solve. Significant inequalities in the bargaining power of suppliers and purchasers are commonly found in the agricultural and food supply chain. All this leads to unfair commercial practices in cases where larger and stronger trading partners try to impose certain practices or contractual clauses that are to their advantage. Some practices could be manifestly unfair, even when both parties agree with them. The new European legislation prohibits, for the first time, up to sixteen unfair commercial practices imposed unilaterally by a partner in a trade relationship. Other practices may be permitted only if they are the subject of prior, clear and unambiguous agreement between the parties concerned. I want us all to understand that we respect any supermarket or hypermarket food distributor, but that, regardless of the name of this brand or what country it comes from, everyone must comply with national and European law, as well as avoid unfair commercial practices.

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my great appreciation for the tenacious, valuable and effective work carried out by my colleague, Mr De Castro. The text agreed with the Council on the proposal for a directive on unfair commercial practices in business relations in the food supply chain is a fundamental and due instrument.  In a market-oriented context of agricultural policy, the good and equitable management of the food supply chain has acquired fundamental importance, particularly for small agricultural producers, who are particularly vulnerable to unfair commercial practices, as they often lack bargaining power corresponding to that of their partners who buy their products.  This is mainly due to the limited alternatives available to them in order to get their products to final consumers, as well as to the structural shortcomings of the agricultural system. The directive aims to target unfair commercial practices through the introduction of protection instruments common to the whole of the European Union, including a wider list of prohibited practices.  The aim of achieving which I can assure you of is to help ensure a fair standard of living for the farming community, thereby achieving one of the main objectives of the CAP. I believe that this is also a legislative measure of great importance for Italian and Sicilian farmers in particular.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the De Castro report has the merit of seeking to combat the unfair practices of mass distribution, which strangle farmers by forcing them to give up their products at a low price. That's why I'll vote for it. But this must not absolve the European Union of its heavy responsibility in the current crisis, which is driving our farmers to despair and, alas, sometimes to suicide. The free trade treaties that the Union negotiates with agricultural giants, such as Canada, Australia, New Zealand or Brazil, are folly because they deliberately organise unfair competition to our detriment. Our farmers must respect social, health and environmental rules that are not imposed on farmers in these countries. This unbridled ultraliberalism has also led the European Union to recently abolish milk and sugar quotas that stabilized milk and sugar prices. We, the Members of the National Rally, had protested against this suppression. We were right, because we are now seeing the sinister effects. The German company, S-dzucker, has just announced the closure of two sugar mills in France, in Eppeville and Cagny. In Eppeville in 12ville, the closure changed the lives of 132 employees and 1,268 betteraviers. I ask the Union, and in particular the Brussels Commission, not to play Pontius Pilate and to acknowledge their wrongs. I ask them to take advantage of the preparation of the new Common Agricultural Policy to further support our model of quality family farming against the American-inspired ultra-liberal agribusiness model, which is destroying our jobs and our health.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate our colleague and Professor Paolo de Castro on the outcome of the negotiations, which is the result of a clear commitment to the defence of farmers.  This Directive is an important step in strengthening farmers' negotiating position and increasing their protection against abusive commercial practices. It will, in a harmonised way, introduce a common minimum level of protection throughout the European Union in addition to the provisions already adopted in some countries, such as Portugal.  This certainly contributes to the practice of fairer prices paid to producers.  We must also highlight here, among other things, the decisive role of the European Parliament in improving the Commission's initial proposal, in particular by contributing to the significant increase in the number of practices covered and the inclusion within its scope of buyers outside the European Union.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President, the high concentration of shops, the exploitation of the small farmer, the consequent consumer problems have brought this European Parliament together in this composition, which will be happy to endorse Mr De Castro's excellent report, for which I thank him. The resolution drafted by Mrs McGuinness has been confirmed and – thank you, Commissioner, for your contribution, which has had enough courage and also perseverance, that, together with the Austrian Presidency, you and our former colleague Köstinger brought the directive back before us in a quick time so that it can come into force. As we know, it is now the turn of the Member States, which will have to leash this directive within two years and protect the farmer, to protect the consumer from unfair trading practices. As many as 16 are enacted here, many more, if they so judge, can be enacted by the Member States and ensure that a sustainable chain, the food supply chain, will be in place in the future. There were too many farms that had to leave this market, because income, income, earnings were distributed unfairly. The fact that only 21% of the income has been left to direct food producers is frightening, and I hope and I am sure that as of today is also a clear signal to consumers, traders, that, even in the future, this regulation will be fairer to those who work in agriculture.

name: Karine GLOANEC MAURIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, while the agricultural sector is living uncertain times across Europe, I too want to commend the effective and energetic work of my colleague Paolo De Castro, but also of the rapporteurs, supported by the European Commission. Well done for this agreement finally found between the co-legislators. It will allow farmers to make a better living from the fruits of their labour and that's all the better: no more last-minute cancellations for perishable goods or unilateral changes to an agreement. From now on, retailers will have to comply with European requirements and stop abusive practices. As you know, European farmers today receive less than a quarter of the value of agricultural product. This proportion is truly unreasonable and endangers all our sectors. In fact, if we are to succeed in the agroecological transition and enhance local production, it is imperative to rebalance the balance of power in favour of small operators. Therefore, this much-anticipated text represents a first step towards a better distribution of value within the agri-food chain and I sincerely hope that this directive, which does not stop at our borders, will be implemented effectively in all Member States.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the end of the mandate is approaching and now, more than ever, our fellow citizens are looking at us waiting for a kind of balance sheet that shows them the importance for their lives of what we have done here. The Directive to combat unfair commercial practices in the agri-food supply chain is a good example of how we defend our farmers and, consequently, all Europeans. Although it has dragged on for years, in this mandate we have had the will, support of all parties and we have reached a very rapid consensus on a directive that will allow greater stability and income security for our farmers and punish all those who abuse their dominance position over the other links in the food chain. It is, therefore, a great day for European agriculture that will see unfair commercial practices enshrined in law, such as unilateral contractual changes, the attempt to impute to farmers the economic losses of distribution, the payment of perishable products within more than 30 days, the imposition of discount schemes or penalties without being agreed in advance , among many others.  The possibility for a producer organisation to lodge a complaint on behalf of one of its members is also a major step towards ending expressions and fears, especially in small markets or in which they accepted the conditions given to them or would no longer provide such an entity. I end, Mr President, with the conviction that this European Parliament has left the agricultural sector a little more protected than it has found. It is a very happy day for European agriculture.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, agricultural policy is a pillar of the European Union and provides massive financial support to farmers and producers, but increasingly, unfortunately, together with trade policies, it comes under accusation, because our farmers are being crushed by unequal labour costs, structural deficiencies and the excessive power of large-scale distribution, which imposes unfair commercial practices. In this way, the weakest links in the supply chain succumb, often reacting by lashing out at Europe, against us who are their representatives.  With this directive, we are finally showing where we stand: on the side of European farmers, producers, consumers, in support of the south and regions – such as my own, Sicily – where the economy is mainly agricultural and agri-food has hundreds of excellences that must be supported and protected. From tomorrow it will be possible to do so, thanks to the effective work carried out by our Vice-President, Mr De Castro, the Commission and all those like me who have always been fighting to protect farmers and small producers, a symbol of our agri-food industry.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my, European model of order is the eco-social market economy. This includes regulating the market. This includes, above all, regulating the market in one direction, so that weaker market participants are not penalised by the overwhelming supremacy of the large ones.  That is exactly what we are doing with the directive on unfair commercial practices in the food chain. We are ending the existing fouls of large retail chains at the expense of farmers and other economically dependent suppliers. And we are ending the sorts of things, such as late payments or the short-term cancellation of supplies, because they could threaten the economic viability of farmers.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are also putting an end to the fact that business relations can be unfair and not designed for the benefit of both sides by preventing there being no longer any refusal to fix contracts in writing. I am therefore also pleased that we are extending this regulation to third countries, that we are creating anonymous complaints for farmers and an alternative dispute settlement procedure. I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency for its contribution to finally ending unfair trade practices.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I’m not a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development but obviously – coming from Ireland, a very strong agricultural country – I take a great interest in this issue, and I remember during my first term in Parliament, six or seven years ago, attending a number of meetings and a work group, with Mairead McGuiness and Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, where this issue was discussed. I also remember that when Commissioner Hogan was first appointed he said this was one of the issues he was going to tackle, and many people didn’t believe him at the time, because they thought it was impossible to do so. In fairness, he has delivered, as has Parliament, and therefore I think we can be happy with the results. The whole lot of the unfair practices, involving aid payments, perishable goods, non-perishable goods, contracts, ‘hello money’, etcetera, have been dealt with. One important point, though, was mentioned by my colleague Jim Nicholson: he said all this was great, and it is, but it must be implemented and monitored properly at Member State level to ensure that the benefits are there for farmers. This is especially so at a time when they are very concerned, I know, in my own country about bad weather, falling prices and, in particular, Brexit. One message that goes out clearly from this process is that if the European Parliament and the Commission are standing behind the farmers in relation to this issue, and can take effective action, I’m quite sure the same will apply in relation to Brexit, if it does happen – although, if Mr Agnew’s prediction is correct, which we hope it is, then it may not happen at all, which would be a perfect solution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. Chairman, the latest survey involving agricultural producers and agricultural cooperatives, conducted on the basis of a broader definition of UTPs, showed that the damage caused by UTPs is estimated at more than €10 billion per year at European level. It is unfair commercial practices that young people cite as one of the main obstacles to farming. Unless this problem is resolved soon, the future of agriculture and food supplies will be challenged.  Farmers are already working in the lowest average income sector in the European Union and do not feel safe. In addition, suppliers and purchasers, as stronger throughout the food supply chain, translate the different risks of their business to farmers as weaker in this chain, be it long payment deadlines, delivery, storage and sales conditions, which farmers themselves cannot influence.  That is why I welcome the swift agreement reached in the trilogue on this legislative proposal and consider it a victory for the small over the big ones, which should make life easier for farmers in the Common European Market.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I apologise for coming too late. I was present at the vote in the Committee on Economic and Industrial Policy until the end, so I was only able to arrive here a little late. I believe that we can all now state that the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in small-scale agricultural production, has always been an important concern of many forces in this House, and the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has always listened to this. That is why, of course, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to the fact that this directive has now been produced, in particular the rapporteur, Mr de Castro. However, I think I have to make it clear that this directive, Commissioner, has not been a perfect success in all areas. The protection of the companies that are now included in the scope of application goes far beyond the definition of what small and medium-sized enterprises have been up to now. One can, of course, raise the question of whether we need a broader definition of 'small and medium-sized enterprises'. But if you ask yourself this question, you actually need an impact assessment in Europe. That is why I have some doubts as to whether we can now shake off an extension of the definition of SMEs from the agricultural sector or whether we would not have needed a little more time to do so. The second problem that I think arises is that this directive actually assumes that we also have a single European market in the agricultural sector. In this respect, it would have been logically imperative to bring this directive to full harmonisation and not to explicitly place further fragmentation in recitals 16 and 17 of the Member States. This, of course, puts the uniformity of this market into question to some extent. All in all, we will agree to this, but there remain some doubts. We will have to see how this matter develops in the future.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, as many have said, this is legislation for which we have been campaigning for years. Thank you, Commissioner Hogan, for putting it on the table, and a big thank you to Paolo De Castro for making it happen before the end of this parliamentary term and before Brexit. I am speaking for the Committee on Development and the most important thing for us is that this legislation covers not just EU farmers but also farmers in the global South, because they too face a squeeze, as farmers here do, and they have very little bargaining power. Take bananas: only 4% to 9% of the value goes to the farmer. Or look at cocoa: a 30-40% drop in income last year. If you think about it, prices are not going down, so somebody, somewhere, is making money, and it is not farmers. Finally, this is a very good piece of legislation. We now need to build upon it, and I want to thank, too, all the campaigners across Europe from the Fair Trade movement, from Traidcraft in the UK, from the Fair Trade Advocacy Office and the cooperative movement, and all those who campaigned for this. Let us hope that, in the new Parliament, we will continue to work on value change, conflict minerals, textiles, cocoa and other commodities, building on the legislation we have before us.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, the success of the negotiations on unfair commercial practices is a real revolution for European producers within this Parliament. With the adoption of this directive, we put an end to the "fear" factor for farmers. With this Directive, we clearly establish a minimum list of prohibited unfair commercial practices between buyers, on the one hand, and suppliers and producers on the other. No more delays of payments of more than 60 days, refusal to enter into a written delivery agreement, commercial repression or threat of such if recourse is made to the search for the rights. These are just a few examples of practices that will need to be completely banned. Payment of a "promotion" fee without prior agreement and before the entry into force of the agreement for the delivery or return of unsold goods will also cease. I call on all Member States, including Bulgaria, to set up adequate committees with legal powers as soon as possible to monitor and ensure the smooth implementation of this Directive.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, unfair commercial practices in business-to-business relations in the food supply chain are on the agenda. We know that in practice there is no fair trade. We know that in practice there is over-exploitation of farmers. It has also been said that farmers themselves at most get 20 % of the total price that a product gets, and that is because there are multinational companies, there are the big food and distribution chains, there are the blackmails by the wholesaler, who shapes prices, often pays by cheques, then he does not pay all that, of course. , lead to a complete dependence on the rural world.  That is why we need a very specific ban on unfair practices, the support of our farmers, but, of course, this is not a panacea. Farmers must also rely on other practices and, above all, have banks to give them cheap credit, to cope with expensive production costs.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan first and foremost. I believe that this directive is absolutely necessary if we are to allow our farmers in Europe to survive.  Finally, this directive will put an end to 16 unfair commercial practices. With this directive, we will ensure a level playing field and a strengthened position of farmers. It will be done, colleagues, with last-minute cancellations of orders. It will be done unilaterally amending agreements and it will be done with refusing written agreements.  Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a Eurobarometer survey from 2017 found that a staggering 88% of respondents called for strengthening the position of farmers in the chain. With this directive we will do so, and I hope that the Member States will implement it very quickly, so that we can better support the farmers of Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, Portuguese farmers now have less than 20 % of the price that consumers pay for their products. We all know the predatory role of large distribution in the agricultural sector. We all know the practices of crushing the prices paid to the producer. It is intolerable and it is also regrettable that the European Union has done nothing over these five years. It now appears with this directive on the eve of elections and, it is a case to say, better late than never.  This proposal certainly has positive aspects, but it does not touch on the fundamental. Its mechanisms are insufficient to ensure this simple thing: that prices cover production costs and ensure a decent standard of living for our farmers. This proposal will certainly be a step, but it falls far short of what is needed.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this directive, which, after so many years, will finally protect farmers from the unfair practices of purchasing and distributing companies and bring about a better balance throughout the food chain.  I would like to highlight the specific case that has happened in Sardinia – my region – and I would like to express my solidarity with the situation. I therefore hope that this directive will restore fair rights to all the thousands of operators who have unfortunately worked without them, and I hope that these rights will be recognised.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my compliments to the rapporteur, Mr De Castro. Farmers and agri-food producers, as we know, are unfortunately vulnerable to unfair commercial practices because the agri-food sector is characterised by serious imbalances in the bargaining power between small and large operators, who sometimes impose conditions on their partners that deviate from good faith and commercial correctness and that can also compromise the quality of the products offered to consumers.  Thanks to the directive we are debating today, a common minimum level of protection will finally be introduced throughout the European Union by banning 16 unfair practices unilaterally imposed by one partner to another, such as late payment or last-minute cancellations of orders. The importance of measures to strengthen cooperation between national authorities and the exchange of good practice, in order to ensure uniform application within the Union of the rules and measures contained in the directive, aimed at protecting farmers and ensuring quality products, should be stressed.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, by adopting the first ever Pan-European law that will significantly protect farmers and small businesses from the unfair practices of the big players, we are successfully closing the efforts that we launched here in Parliament with my colleagues Czesak and McGuinness in 2016. It's been almost impossible. Less than three years from scratch, build a tool that ends last-minute cancellations, unilateral treaty changes, or postponed payments. The weaker party will no longer have to fear retaliation through confidentiality, and supervisory authorities will now have to cooperate across Member States. The negotiating positions of players in the food chain are incomparable. However, this law will help a lot to set up fair and transparent relations between manufacturers, suppliers and distributors, so I thank everyone who participated in its adoption.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the widespread support that has been demonstrated tonight for the agreement reached last December and I look forward to this support being reflected in the vote tomorrow. Mr De Castro is 100% right when he says that this legislation will protect 100% of EU farmers. It will also protect 97% of small businesses in the agri-food sector.  We had two very revealing contributions here tonight, from both extremes of the political spectrum. One from Mr Agnew, who actually let the cat out of the bag eventually, and revealed the greatest secret that we knew he was harbouring for so long – that the reason why people that share his view in the House of Commons have been voting against Mrs May’s deal up to now is that they really secretly want to stay in the European Union after all. I know that you’re quite correct when you wave the flag there that you say you will be here in a year’s time. That’s thanks to you and the people that actually think like you who are voting against a deal in order to exit the European Union. (Protests) (Addressing Mr Agnew) No. You’ve got plenty of time to express your view over the years.  The second one is Mr Carthy’s view in relation to this legislation. Presumably speaking on behalf of his group, he now is adopting a very isolationist position, where he is actually supporting the strong versus the weak. I’m absolutely flabbergasted at this political stance of Sinn Féin, in particular, who portrayed themselves as extreme Socialists, with great pride, for many, many years. What we’re trying to do here is go in the right direction and help the weak against the strong. I thought that that very principle would be something that could be shared by Sinn Féin and actually it’s remarkable that he has now put himself in a political position where he’s on the same side as the big supermarket retailers, rather than actually on the side of the farmers who are being 100% protected and the small businesses who are being protected as well, up to EUR 350 million turnover. Nobody is saying, Mr Carthy, that this is going to be a panacea for farm prices overnight, but it’s minimum harmonisation at the European Union level for Member States, including Ireland, if you can persuade them, that will be able to do more in this case. Member States can go further due to the construction of this directive and I hope that they do so, particularly as Mr Andrieu and Mr Loiseau have mentioned, in relation to France. This is an opportunity to bring about much-needed protection for our farmers. With the help of this House, we have seized that opportunity and those who continue to oppose the legislation now make up a bizarre incoherent coalition of interests.  Mr Nicholson is quite correct and so is Ms Aguilera. This is about protecting farmers and you have to actually start somewhere in order to do this. Ms McGuinness and Ms Aguilera, and others, emphasised that what the Commission’s proposal is about, with a strong initiative and support of the farmers, is to respond to calls out there from this House about trying to protect the weak against the strong. We’re strengthening the position of the farmers in the food chain. We’re actually banning unfair trading practices in a number of areas, and I think that 96% of the respondents to our public consultation agreed that we should do this, so I don’t know where the support is for anything other than this. Madam Heubuch, you are free to make more changes in competition law, as you attempted to do in the trilogue process, and in four years’ time, you will have another opportunity. We have made a lot of progress in competition law in relation to agriculture in the last few years through the Omnibus Regulation, through the food chain and we will be making further progress through market transparency rules that I will be publishing in the near future.  The reality of this is that the course is in front of us, but we will only start to work when the Member States take their responsibilities seriously. The EU has done its job, in the words of Mr Dantin, in a noble cause. Now let us join together to ensure the steady transposition of this directive and let us remind ourselves that this is a minimum requirement.  Mr Andrieu, Ms Zoană and others recalled that it has taken some time for there to be a Commission proposal. Let me confirm that this is a proposal that has the full support of the Commission and reflects what President Juncker said in his State of the Union speech here in 2015, when we had a milk crisis and a pigmeat crisis, that it was hard to understand how milk was cheaper than water. So we have made a stand and I say finally, Mr President, to Mr Schwab, that I understand his comments coming from his perspective, but there was a much more ambitious proposal that ultimately was put on the table. We have reached a compromise, and there was a very rigorous impact assessment completed by the Commission before the proposal was tabled. Finally, nothing in this legislation should provide any fear for any sector in the food chain if they are behaving in a proper manner and acting fairly towards the farmer.  (Applause)

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their comments and, once again, I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan for supporting the European Parliament so strongly. Without this team game, we wouldn't have succeeded, colleagues. It is only eight months since the proposal was presented to the political agreement of 19 December, and I would also like to mention the unanimous vote of the Agriculture Council. That is why I expect a positive vote from all my fellow Members, including those who wanted more, and also from those – few, in fact – who did not want this directive at all. Ladies and gentlemen, this is precisely the Europe we want. It is Europe that gives a helping hand to the weakest companies and ensures that consumers have transparent and quality-guaranteeing standards. I agree, once again, with mrs Mairead McGuinness: it is a first step, it is a first step and we must apply it well, this directive. Let us also remember, however, that the directive extends the effectiveness of national laws. So we can remind Mr Agnew that British companies will be better protected now, thanks to the directive, because they will also be protected when they export to other countries of the European Union. I would like to thank Linda McAvan, because she wanted to mention something of which we are proud: the directive also applies to producers outside Europe and therefore protection is extended to all those small producers who may suffer unfair practices here in Europe.  In short, Mr Hogan, dear Phil, we have done a little miracle with this directive. It is all the groups that support you, with the sole exception of my colleague Matt Carthy, which I hope he may reflect on at night.  I would like to thank everyone once again and we hope that a success such as the one that this Parliament has brought home today can be repeated in the future. Thank you all.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, March 12, 2019, at 12.30 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 19 December 2018, the Austrian Presidency and the European Parliament reached agreement on a directive aimed at halting UTPs in business-to-business relations in the agricultural and food supply chain. The main objective of the Directive is to protect farmers who are considered to be the most vulnerable in the food supply chain from buyers who are much larger than them. The Directive will make it possible to create a common European framework ensuring a minimum level of protection for farmers and other suppliers of agri-food products with a turnover of not more than €350 million. This agreement covers food, cut flowers, pet food and animal feed. Eight commercial practices will be completely prohibited, including: delays for perishable products, cancellation of last-minute orders, unilateral or retroactive changes to supply contracts, misuse of confidential information and retaliation or threats against the supplier. All this is aimed at empowering smaller actors (farmers) in the food supply chain.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Small farmers and producers are vital to the European economy and food sector. We should have worked long ago to strengthen the position of small producers and farmers on the market. Today, I am pleased that, thanks to this report, farmers and food supply producers will be defended against unfair practices, such as last-minute cancellation of orders, delays in payments and, in particular, unilateral contract changes.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – I am pleased that, finally, this week we will approve a legislative act to combat unfair commercial practices in the agri-food sector. Unfortunately, only some Member States have adopted national legislation on the regulation of unfair practices and, therefore, this directive is more than necessary. I've been waiting for her and asking for it for a very long time. Small producers, in particular, must be protected in relation to place with 'retailers'. I firmly believe that this directive will help for small farmers to have easier access to supermarkets and that both binding contracts and timely payments will guarantee a safer and more decent income for this type of producer. Unfortunately, only 21% of the final price of a product sold in the supermarket goes to the manufacturer. I hope that, after the implementation of this directive, Romanian producers will be able to have more bargaining power with supermarkets and that they enjoy fair income.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – I support this proposal because I agree with the ban on unfair trading practices applied by retail chains to agricultural and food producers. Unfair practices, such as late payments for perishable foods, last-minute cancellations or unilateral changes to contract terms, are causing significant financial problems for small producers. In this context, it is important to mention the figures from the September 2018 Study of the European Parliament's Research Service (EPRS), which shows that, on average, European farmers receive only around 20% of the total value of food and that processors receive around 28%. The rest, i.e. more than half, will go to the traders themselves. This reflects the unequal position of these actors in the food supply chain. This legislative measure therefore aims to improve the conditions of those whose position is weakest in this food chain, namely small and medium-sized food and agricultural enterprises. Even though the measures introduced by this directive are not, in my view, self-saving, there can be no doubt that they are going in the right direction.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the joint debate on the recommendation by Heidi Hautala, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Voluntary Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam on the application of the rules, governance and trade in the forestry sector (10861/2018 - C8-0445/2018 - 2018/0272(NLE)) (A8-0083/2019), and - Heidi's report Hautala, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, containing a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Voluntary Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam on forest law enforcement, governance and trade (10861/2018 – C8-0445/2018 – 2018/0272M(NLE)) (A8-0093/2019).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I am extremely happy to say that the Voluntary Partnership Agreements on forest law enforcement, governance and trade are an excellent example of combining a trade instrument with sustainable development. There is also a direct link between this Voluntary Partnership Agreement with Vietnam and the European Union and Vietnam Free Trade Agreement: namely, Chapter 13, on sustainable development, of the free trade agreement, which still has to be ratified, has a reference to the implementation of this Voluntary Partnership Agreement. I would like to emphasise that this is an excellent instrument for addressing deficiencies of governance, not only in the forestry sector but in the state system as a whole. I am talking about the functioning of customs, border guards etcetera. Vietnam is now the third country in Asia that has entered Voluntary Partnership Agreement negotiations with the European Union and I am extremely happy that Vietnam has committed to eradicating illegal timber from its supply chains. I visited Vietnam in January in my role as rapporteur. My hosts emphasised that Vietnam’s aim is to become the world’s biggest producer of timber products. This is all the more reason to ensure that Vietnam sources and processes only legal timber. Vietnam has a new forestry law in force since January this year. It unequivocally prohibits imports of illegal timber. This effectively means that timber imports from Cambodia should no longer take place – and here work needs to be done, including with Cambodia. In that context, it is also extremely worrying that Global Witness has found a surge in imports from the Democratic Republic of Congo, which is known to be a high-risk country. This issue has to be tackled in the course of the implementation of the Voluntary Partnership Agreement. It is of critical importance that Vietnam makes sure illegal imports are effectively stopped: simply relocating the sourcing to new high-risk countries is clearly not the solution. I expect Vietnam to enforce its forestry law swiftly and effectively, and it should consult all the stakeholders. The EU is ready to help.  – Mr President, the EU for its part should ensure sufficient resources in supporting Vietnam while it implements the crucial reforms. The EU is also in the process of drafting a new action plan on deforestation and forest degradation. Innovations similar to the Voluntary Partnership Agreements are required in order to address the global challenge of deforestation. As we know, deforestation has become ever more critical as the scientific understanding of its importance to climate change has grown. The Voluntary Partnership Agreements are a crucial part of the solution, as legal instruments are needed to step up the fight against deforestation globally. The EU needs to put in place strong measures to eradicate fully deforestation from European products that it wants to export to us and from the supply chains. By the way, this approach could also be applied to other risk products such as coffee, cocoa and palm oil. Vietnam is facing a huge task. After the ratification, which is expected to happen tomorrow, it will have to fulfil the commitments of this agreement. I have all the confidence that Vietnam will tackle this challenge with the seriousness that it deserves. This is not, and certainly cannot be, a mere bx-ticking exercise. Only once this Parliament is fully assured of the complete implementation and once it is convinced of the eradication of illegal timber from Vietnamese wood products will it be able to agree to issue licensees to Vietnam.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU Vietnam Voluntary Partnership Agreement is an important milestone in our relations with Vietnam, it is an important step in our battle against illegal logging and deforestation, and it is an important affirmation of the validity of the EU’s longstanding Action Plan on Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade. It is the first voluntary partnership agreement signed with a country that is not only an important exporter but also a significant importer of timber. Vietnam is at the very centre of the global timber products trade. That is why the Voluntary Partnership Agreement with Vietnam, once implemented and fully operational, has great potential for creating a positive impact well beyond Vietnamese borders and, at the same time, bringing social, economic and environmental benefits to the Vietnamese people. I am pleased to see that the European Parliament agrees with this assessment, as shown by the two resolutions we have before us today. I can only repeat some of the important points highlighted in the reports. Vietnam has made remarkable progress since the start of the negotiations. One major success has been the open and constructive participation by everyone in Vietnam who was relevant to the process, which we hope and expect will continue in the implementation phase. Vietnam will introduce mandatory due diligence obligations for its importers. We are proud of this achievement but we are also aware that it will be our duty to ensure that its implementation does not fall short of the high due diligence standards established by our own EU Timber Regulation. The issue of the legality of imports, especially those from Cambodia, has been at the heart of the debates, and rightly so. We will continue to monitor the situation very closely. However, we should remember that import controls are only one element of a comprehensive system designed to ensure timber legality beyond the import points. It also covers harvesting, processing, trade in and export of timber products. Ultimately, the success of this Voluntary Partnership Agreement will be measured by the credible and robust implementation of the timber legality assurance system as a whole. There can be no forest law enforcement, governance and trade licensing without this. I welcome the overall positive message on this agreement that comes from Parliament’s resolutions. I look forward to our debates on this landmark agreement.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, as a rapporteur for the Committee on Development (DEVE), I have been fully supportive of this Voluntary Partnership Agreement (VPA) between EU and Vietnam. This is necessary, useful and innovative in its mechanism and logic. We know that Vietnam is a major exporter of timber products to the EU and to other countries in the region around Vietnam, like Japan and China, and this VPA will act in the future as an effective instrument to fight against illegal trade and to promote sustainable trade in timber products. However, let me stress one thing. I am happy about the conclusion of this particular treaty, but on the other hand, I remain worried about its sister file, the EU-Vietnam free trade agreement, for which I am EP standing rapporteur. We have delays, obstacles and procedural complications and I would like to urge the Commission to try to push the Romanian Presidency a little bit to move this treaty further on so that we can vote on it before the elections in May.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, today we are discussing yet another trade agreement. It’s the last in this parliamentary term after Japan and Singapore. It warms my heart to see that we are opening our markets to high-standard trade. I have always spoken in favour of trade agreements as they boost trade, promote international competitiveness of our companies, as well as create opportunities for investments outside of the EU.  I cannot stress enough the importance of the whole process. We should be proud that we now have over 70 preferential trade agreements in place. One thing is to stimulate economic growth, but we cannot forget about sharing our norms and values, as well as promoting social inclusion and environmental protection. I believe that this House should give its consent as fast as possible to this agreement so that we can focus on the implementation so that everyone can benefit from it as quickly as possible.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Ms Hautala on her report. I really welcome this agreement with Vietnam, committing now to only importing and exporting legally harvested timber. This is especially important given that this country is a leader in timber products. Deforestation, as we’ve already heard, is the second leading cause of global warming and this agreement will be key, not only in achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, but also the Paris climate change goals. However, I do have some questions for the Commission. Firstly, there is an urgent need to address the regional dimension of the rampant illegal logging. Therefore, I’d like to know: what efforts the Commission has undertaken to tackle illegal timber trade from supplier countries like Laos and Cambodia? Secondly, what is the state of play with the new Voluntary Partnership Agreement (VPA) with China, which is also a crucial player in the processed wood industry? Finally, to what extent has the EU Timber Regulation been raised in dialogue with Japan as another major importer of timber and a trading partner of the EU?

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Hautala. Prevention of deforestrum and the growth of carbon sinks are indeed issues that have a significant impact in the fight against climate change. This issue needs to be looked at in a very broad way. We need to look at long-term development and also at the global perspective. At the same time, care must be taken to ensure that forests are managed sustainably at local level, of which there are good examples of this in Europe, for example from Finland. I am pleased that the EU is giving its support to Vietnam through this voluntary partnership agreement. Vietnam has taken the right steps in the sustainability of forestry and is now committed to ensuring that timber products and timber imported into the EU are legally produced. This will also improve the development of the forest sector in the vicinity of Vietnam. I would also like to support a comprehensive and very modern trade agreement between Vietnam and the EU that would bring more jobs and prosperity to Vietnam and Europe. It is in Europe's interest to have the trade agreement in force quickly, because that is the only way to ensure that the standards that are important to us are met.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this report. My group welcomes the agreement on sustainable forestry with Vietnam. It can become an international model for reconciling the creation of economic prospects for the population and the protection of nature and the climate. This is an important building block for achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals by 2030, especially in Southeast Asia. Vietnam still has a difficult way to go before it actually to stop the trade in illegally cut timber and to implement the agreement. It must also include the existing routes for illegal timber from Laos and Cambodia through Vietnam. We should provide more support to our FLEGT partners in Asia and Africa in their work with expertise and funding, because the FLEGT programmes have been able to reduce illegal trade by 20%. But the UN still has to quantify the loss of tax revenue from illegal timber trade at 15 billion a year. The damage to biodiversity and climate is even more serious. That is why the EU Commission should press for the cooperation of our trading partners to dismantle overexploitation as a business model and to promote effectively sustainable timber in Southeast Asia.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to underline the fact that Vietnam is the European Union’s second largest trading partner in the Association of South-East Asian Nations and also one of the most dynamic emerging countries in the East Asia region. This agreement follows on from many previous forest law enforcement governance and trade agreements with countries in Africa and Indonesia, and it builds on the work of the EU Timber Regulation. As a Member of the Committee on Development, I have to stress here that I support this agreement. The issue of indigenous communities must also be kept in mind. As we know, indigenous communities are often heavily reliant on forests, and very often are the victims of environmental exploitation. It is important to ensure that the agreement complements the EU commitments to environment protection. We do not want these agreements to be seen as a framework for large-scale exploitation of forests. There must be coherence between the agreements and our commitments to prevent mass deforestation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Vietnam is one of the largest timber producers in the world and, of course, an important trading partner of the European Union. This voluntary agreement really, if properly respected and implemented, can help to tackle poaching. It is certain that de-affation must stop, we must rely on efforts that really strengthen environmental conditions that ensure that the problems of climate change are addressed.  Of course, there are many problems, because there is illegal import of timber into Vietnam from Cambodia and this is largely due to the corruption that exists in customs, in the customs authorities of Vietnam. If this is not addressed, we will obviously not be able to have a serious and proper implementation of the agreement that we are seeing. It is therefore a matter for Vietnam to respect the terms and conditions of this voluntary agreement.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased with this resolution. My constituents in Poland are very interested in the issue of forests in Vietnam. People in my country listen to such debates with baked goods on their faces simply. name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their support and for bringing the Commission’s attention to their concerns about the implementation of the Agreement and the situation on the ground in Vietnam. There was a question about the regional initiative dimensions. There is a voluntary partnership agreement process with Laos, a dialogue with Cambodia, and a bilateral cooperation mechanism with China, where the legality of timber is a priority. We are also having a dialogue with Japan.  The messages that I have heard today are clear: we must work with our Vietnamese partners to set out an ambitious course for this Agreement to be implemented effectively. I can assure you that the Commission is committed and ready to do this. At the same time, the Commission looks forward to building on the positive experience with the Voluntary Partnership Agreement on forest law enforcement, governance and trade in the context of our broader relationship with Vietnam. This includes our future EU—Vietnam trade and investment agreements and the EU-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Agreements. The Commission will of course be happy to inform the Parliament on progress in the implementation of the Voluntary Partnership Agreement with Vietnam and on how the points raised in the resolution are being addressed.  Finally, I would like to recall that, by giving your consent, you are not only supporting this Voluntary Partnership Agreement. You are also reaffirming the importance and relevance of the Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade Action Plan, which since 2003 has shaped the EU’s fight against illegal logging – a significant driving force behind deforestation. This support is valuable to us as we see this Action Plan as a prime example of environment, development and trade policies acting in a mutually supportive way. We also need this kind of policy coherence to address broader deforestation challenges, and it will guide our approach as we further develop our policies in this area.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I want to thank you, Commissioner, and your colleagues. We did a great job together, and it is a pleasure to see that the whole Parliament is likely to support this Voluntary Partnership Agreement between the EU and Vietnam. This is probably the most effective trade instrument we have in order to combat the negative developments that are making it impossible to implement true sustainable development.  So let us use this instrument and see that there is, as the Commissioner and colleagues have pointed out, this regional dimension: we have to be aware that Southeast Asia is one of the three hot spots of deforestation in the world. The second is the Congo Basin and the third one is Latin America. In all these areas, we have Voluntary Partnership Agreements under way. I expect the Commission to take the recent revelations of organised crime, illegal logging and illegal timber trade in Southeast Asia extremely seriously. This has been shown by the Environmental Inspection Agency in Myanmar, and we now have credible allegations that Vietnam has started to replace imports from Cambodia with imports from the DRC. The DRC is something that we have to look into in terms of the illegal timber trade. I am very happy to hear from the Commission that it will inform the European Parliament about the different steps in the implementation of this Voluntary Partnership Agreement. I believe that the two committees that have been most involved – the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Development – will gain more and more interest in this instrument. Thank you very much and I hope that tomorrow we can ratify the agreement and the accompanying non-legislative resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by György Schöpflin, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Citizens' Initiative (COM(2017)0482 - C8-0308/2017 - 2017/0220(COD)) (A8-0226/2018).

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Acting Rapporteur. Mr President, my first words will be to express what is the wish of the whole of this House, which is that our colleague Gy-rgy Spflin, who is currently hospitalized for a serious illness, will recover quickly and completely. I would like to point out that the aim of the European Citizens' Initiative is to give citizens, if there are enough of them and come from a quarter of the European countries, a right of political initiative comparable to that which this Parliament has, through the resolutions that we vote on each month and which the Council of Ministers has: the possibility of taking the European Commission to invite it to legislate in a new area , to stop legislating or to amend previous legislation. The first regulation that we adopted a few years ago to serve as the legal basis for the system was quite disappointing, as there are only four citizen initiatives that have reached the final phase of the process. That is why we have put the book back on the job and, in good agreement between the European Commission, Commissioner Timmermans, and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, we have come up with a new proposal, which has resulted in a trilogue agreement, and this agreement has been approved in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs by 18 votes in support, no votes against and only three abstentions. The new life cycle, which is thus introduced into this regulation of the citizens' initiative, essentially at the initiative of Parliament, allows for a simpler, more accessible, less expensive and more transparent process, it introduces the possibility of partial registration of a citizens' initiative whose initial aim might be to break the limits of the Treaty, it obliges the European Commission to present its legal and political conclusions within a limited period of six months , and it also obliges - and the NGOs concerned - the European Parliament to hold a debate before the European Commission decides on its responsibilities; and finally, it gives Parliament the opportunity to adopt a motion for a resolution. You will recall that our Parliament has amended its internal rules to make this possibility effective. The revision of the regulation also ensures greater transparency of funding. It establishes contact points, an online register allowing the group of organisers to manage their initiative throughout the process and, with the aim of the Commission by 2020, setting up a central system for collecting declarations of support online. This system already exists, but is simply optional. It is expected to be fully finalized by next year. It's also free. This was one of the requests for simplification and technical assistance from the NGOs with which we worked. It would appear that other NGOs or others were, at the very last moment, concerned about this procedure, but there is no need to question the content of this trilogue. Therefore, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I formally recommend to our plenary that we confirm the excellent agreement that has been obtained in the trilogue.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr Lamassoure, I would like to join in your good wishes to Mr Lamassoure. Mr Schöpflin, who I know very well as a committee colleague. I hope and pray that you will be able to return here with us in good health.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate concludes the revision process of the European Citizens’ Initiative, one of the political priorities of the Juncker Commission. It allows one million people to invite the Commission to make a legal proposal on a topic that matters to them. Since the scheme became operational almost seven years ago, more than nine million people have signed the Citizens’ Initiative. As such, the initiatives are an important instrument to promote and stimulate their participation in the democratic life of the European Union, allowing them to initiate European debates and help set the agenda of EU institutions. Two pending Commission proposals are in direct response to citizens’ initiatives. The proposed revision of the Drinking Water Directive, now under discussion, and the proposal on transparency and sustainability of risk assessment in the food chain, where the institutions have reached a political agreement. The Commission has proposed a revised regulation for the European Citizens’ Initiative to realise its full potential. It is essential that people are helped and further encouraged to use this instrument without unnecessary obstacles or burdens standing in their way. The text agreed between Parliament and Council will make the European Citizens’ Initiative more accessible and user-friendly at all stages of the cycle. It will offer more opportunities for initiative organisers to receive support and advice, in particular, through an online collaborative platform and contact points in Member States. It will help organisers by improving the registration process and giving them a more flexible timeline to start their campaigns. The Commission will provide organisers with a free service for the online collection of signatures. It will simplify the personal data that people have to provide in order to sign. Everyone will be able to sign no matter where they live. There will also be more time and, therefore, awareness raising, engagement and debates on successful initiatives before the Commission replies. The Commission regrets that some of the objectives which it wanted to pursue in this reform and which it shared with Parliament could not be fully achieved. In the end, it was not possible to lower the participation age from 18 to 16 across the EU. However, each Member State has the possibility to lower it for their own citizens if they wish to do so. We hope that many will do this because the voices of younger generations deserve to be heard.  In addition, while the new regulation introduces a central online collection system that the Commission provides for free, we would have preferred to retain the option for organisers to use their own systems if they wish. As a compromise between co-legislators, this possibility will be phased out by the end of 2022. However, I would like to stress that the Commission is fully committed to delivering a high-quality central system, which we will develop in close consultation with stakeholders.  All in all, I believe we have already delivered on our objective to make the European Citizens’ Initiative more accessible, less burdensome and easier to use. I would like to thank the European Parliament, particularly the rapporteur, Mr Schöpflin, for its continued commitment to reforming the European Citizens’ Initiative and its contribution to achieving this very positive outcome.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Rapporteur, Committee on Culture and Education. – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, first of all, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education, I would like to thank My Colleague Schöpflin and the other fellow rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for the work at work at work and good cooperation. I believe that the result achieved after the trilogue negotiations is balanced and gives citizens access to a more organised and facilitated system for registering the citizens' initiative than we have so far. The European Citizens' Initiative is a crucial democratic instrument of the European Union. It allows European citizens to participate directly in the creation of European norms and written rules. The problem in the current system comes from an extremely cumbersome and slow process for organisers, which is also complex for those supporting the initiative.  Indeed, in the main proposal for change we saw a number of positive changes. These include the possibility of easier registration, greater freedom to choose the date for collecting signatures, as well as an increase in the requirement for completeness of personal data. Nevertheless, I wanted to see a deeper initiative. Thanks for the attention, though.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Mr President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Schupflin on his work and underline the good climate of cooperation with Commissioner Timmermans and the Austrian Presidency. The result is satisfactory. Our aim was to reform the European Citizens' Initiative and to offer a tool to citizens. From the point of view of the Committee on Petitions, the contract is fulfilled: the organisers of an initiative will have the opportunity to present in detail their initiatives in the context of a public hearing in Parliament. The intention here was also to represent all public and private interests. We have failed to convince the Commission and the Council to ensure a presence at the highest level of these two institutions. In that respect, we have been somewhat vague. Both Commissioner Timmermans and the Austrian Presidency are studying the issue and we still hope to have the presence of the President of the Commission or a very high-ranking person, for example a minister of the rotating Presidency of the Council.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. This is an important moment for European democracy. The European Parliament and we, its members, have said from the outset that the European citizens' initiative needs to be improved and simplified. We cannot ignore people's proposals to the Union. This is the only way the Union can become a citizens' union, and this requires a smoother process and clearer rules. Looks like things are changing today. In the space of a few months, the Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled in two cases against the European Commission. It is the registration of two EU citizens' initiatives to strengthen the protection of the rights of indigenous minorities in Europe on the so-called 'minority safe pack' and the 'Cohesion Policy for the equality of regions and the sustainability of regional cultures'. Earlier, registration of the two initiatives was rejected by the Commission. It turned out to be wrong. The successful collection of signatures by safe pack has shown how important this issue is for Europeans, as much more signatures have been collected than required. Even with the second court ruling, it looks like another signature-gathering operation is under way. I am therefore convinced that the issue of EU citizens, including indigenous minorities, must continue to be a priority, and this initiative will help us to do so.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Citizens' Initiative has been in existence for almost seven years now. Since the entry into force of the regulation, more than nine million people have signed a citizens' initiative. This shows that citizens want this instrument of cross-border participatory democracy. The other side of the coin, however, is that, unfortunately, only four citizens' initiatives have been able to collect the necessary number of one million signatures in at least seven Member States. In my opinion, practice has shown that this was not primarily due to the issues raised, but that the administrative and technical barriers to citizen participation were obviously too high. It is good that, with the reform package, we are now clearing many of these hurdles. For example, firstly, all EU citizens will be able to support a citizens' initiative in the future, regardless of their place of residence. Secondly, in future, contact points in the Member States will advise organisers on all practical issues. Thirdly, if a citizens' initiative submitted is only partially permitted, the Commission can now allow it instead of having to declare it completely inadmissible. Fourthly, organizers will be given more time to prepare their campaigns. You can now choose when to start collecting signatures. Fifthly, in future, our Parliament will hold a public hearing on every successful citizens' initiative in order to raise awareness of the concern of an initiative, and we have already amended our Rules of Procedure for this. These and other improvements will make the citizens' initiative more user-friendly. There is, however, a downside. My group has argued in favour of significantly rejuvenating the citizens' initiative by lowering the minimum age to 16. Young people are very interested in politics; At the moment, they are taking to the streets in wind and weather to make their concerns heard, be it for a sustainable climate policy or for a free Internet. They want to get involved, and they should be able to do so. Unfortunately, however, the Council has resisted lowering the minimum age. It is therefore at least a step in the right direction that the Member States have now been given the opportunity to decide for themselves on the minimum age of 16. I very much hope that there will be a committed public debate on this and that it will soon be normal throughout the EU for young people to be allowed to support citizens' initiatives, because our Europe needs the participation of young people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Citizens' Initiative is a concrete expression of participatory democracy and should therefore be strengthened within the European Union. The fact that 9 million citizens of the European Union have so far participated in various citizens' initiatives shows the massive participation and the fact that a legislative initiative on drinking water is already being launched shows the success of the effort. However, the whole process should be more simplified, the Commission should not have the dominant role, which is what the citizens are calling for to legislate, but it must itself check whether the initiatives are correct. Therefore, the new procedure is particularly important, we discussed it in the Committee on Petitions and of course the right of the organisers to have a public hearing and in the European Parliament I think it broadens the democratic side of the operation. I support the effort to have the maximum participation of young people, 16 years old young people being able to participate in the whole effort. The fact that the Council does not allow it is negative, but the states themselves can give this opportunity and I believe that the Greek Government should give this opportunity. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: 'blue card' question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been told of a citizens' initiative that has brought together more than two million people, for the respect of life, from conception to death. This citizens' initiative, which I am also told to support, has not been recognised, not accepted by Parliament, supposedly because it would be against the fundamentals of the institution. I would like you to tell me what you know and what you think.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: answer a question with a blue card. – I would like to say this: that the procedure provides for both the position of the Commission and the position of the European Parliament. However, to the extent that there is disagreement, I believe that those responsible could go to the Court of Justice of the European Union, as was the case with the other initiatives, and determine, from then on, whether this was legal or illegal. Ultimately, the application of legality is ensured by the judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union, to which the competent authorities may appeal.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, improving and facilitating the exercise of the European citizens' initiative is a contribution to democracy and the necessary approach of citizens to European affairs. It is good news to note that many of the improvements that have been made to this report to make the exercise of this right more useful, accessible and simple come from the citizens themselves.  I also say this from the knowledge that I have lived very closely through the process followed by one of these initiatives, Minority Safe Pack, which has obtained the minimum number of signatures needed in twelve Member States to submit it for consideration. The proposal responds to the difficulties I experienced so closely. I hope that the improvements will increase the number of initiatives that are being put forward, that of citizens who are involved in promoting them and that of those who are allowed to process.  It is a good idea that public hearings are held in Parliament on initiatives, that they should be discussed in plenary and there will be a motion for a resolution. It is also positive that the deadline available to the proponents to collect support and the Commission to accept or reject the proposals should be made more flexible. And also to objectively improve the platforms and technical resources available to the proponents of their own motion.  It would be a good idea for its language regime to adapt to the whole cultural diversity of the Union. Speakers of minority languages who claimed respect for them in the Minority Safe Pack found that the available tools were not offered in those languages which are official in several regions of the Member States.  It's a problem of sensitivity and proximity. That is why I call for the regional and local level to gain prominence in the promotion of this instrument of citizen participation and to be able to collaborate in the promotion of such matters.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we have been working on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) for the past four years. The first drafts could not count on the approval of my group, Greens/EFA, since they were really weak. Now we have come to a final text, which improves enormously on the old ones – even if it is not completely satisfactory.  First I would like to underline the good outcomes of our negotiations even if I repeat things already said by my colleagues. One, now there is a possibility for the organisers to be registered as legal entities. Two, translations of the annexes of the ECIs are included with a reasonable restriction in the number of characters to be translated for free. Three, it will be possible for partial registration. Four, organisers can choose on which date to start. Five, it is possible to collect emails for the purposes of information on a particular ECI. Six, all EU citizens will be able to sign an ECI no matter where they reside. Seven, an extremely important point is the expected follow-up: the European Parliament will make two follow-ups: one after the hearing and one after the communication from the Commission. It is of the utmost importance that the European Parliament gains this presence and intervention. I have to mention a negative point in relation to what Mr Lamassoure said on this point. Individual online collection systems will only be allowed until the end of 2022 but not beyond this date. That’s the reason why the NGOs protested, some of them very strongly. In any case, we also resent very much the backwards step of not allowing the individual online collection system to be available indefinitely. But at the end of the day if we take a comprehensive look at the file, if we consider gains and losses, we have to accept that the global proposal of the ECI regulations means a very important step forward. That’s why I commend to my Group to ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

The union's established powers are barricaded by closing the doors to citizen participation at the precise moment when they glorify the European demos. It's not a...
