name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the amendment of the Regulation on the European Citizens' Initiative, I too believe that we have wasted an opportunity to bring citizens closer to the European institutions. Instead of strengthening an instrument created to stem the democratic deficit that characterises the current European Union, the compromise reached between Parliament and the Council in some ways weakens this instrument. To date, according to the limits imposed by the Treaties, there is no obligation on the European Commission to present a legislative proposal on the subject under the citizens' initiative, even if it has all the requirements of the regulation. If the compromise reached were therefore to be confirmed, not only could the request coming directly from a million citizens still be ignored or circumvented, but the individual signature collection system, managed directly by the organisers of an ICE, which has so far been essential to make collecting signatures easier in fuelling debate and public awareness of the issues covered by an initiative, would even be deleted. We could also have strengthened this instrument in full compliance with the Treaties, bringing to three the number of hearings planned for each ECI: one during the collection of signatures, another at the reach of one million signatures and finally a follow-up, and not by a simple amendment of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. This would have made it possible to place greater emphasis on the demands made by citizens. Instead, it was the arrogance of those who believe that the best ideas for improving our Union are necessarily those coming from the palaces in Brussels that prevailed. The Commission also remains a player and arbitrator in this process. A role that allows it to choose the proposals that need to be submitted, thus escaping any kind of accountability on the part of the citizens and giving them the feeling that ice is a game rigged from the beginning. We can still remedy this, and that is why tomorrow we will be asking the House to be able to vote on the amendments we have tabled in order to reopen the negotiations and arrive at a text that finally values this important instrument of direct democracy.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I belong to the majority in this Parliament which does not accept a Europe limited to the common market. We want the Europe of the people, the Europe of the citizens. European citizenship is the cornerstone of the European project.  One of the most important innovations of the Lisbon Treaty was undoubtedly the European Citizens' Initiative. We want to strengthen European democracy, stimulate citizen participation and bring elected officials and voters closer together. Since then, more than nine million Europeans from all Member States have participated, including more than 100,000 Portuguese. Let's be clear. This instrument is not enough. We need much more to strengthen the Europe of citizens, to combat apathy and abstention and to prevent the emergence of worrying populist drifts. But we can and must improve this European Citizens' Initiative by simplifying it, providing more resources and emphasising the European Commission's obligation to act. The increased concern about the transparency of funding and support for organisers are also contained in the proposals we are going to adopt. I also support the call for Member States to reduce the age of participation from 18 to 16. We want, Mr President, for more citizens to be able to participate and for all of us to benefit from their interest and initiative, because more democracy certainly means better Europe.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, I believe that the agreement being put to the vote is an interesting agreement because it significantly improves the mechanism of citizen initiative. Firstly, because it encourages States, including the European Commission, to be able to help those with this initiative.  Secondly, because there is an official online signature collection system. Thirdly, because more time is given for the collection of signatures. Fourthly, because Member States can amend their laws so that those over the age of sixteen can vote and be able to support the initiatives. Finally, I would point out the importance of the European Parliament organising a debate on such initiatives.  In my opinion, the short life of the citizen initiative in Europe needed reforms. The ones that have now been agreed with the Commission and the Council are good, and my view is that this will help to make more initiatives and better citizen participation from now on.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, although, since 2012, nine million people from 28 countries have already signed a European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI), a series of shortcomings still unfortunately impede the full potential of this instrument. I would like to underline that the updated ECI will benefit from technological improvements, in particular for collecting signatures online and a collaborative platform. All information and the central collection system will be able to be accessed by people with disabilities, for example. What is important, however, is that the Commission will now be able to partially register the initiative in cases where the Commission only has the power to propose legislation. Furthermore, the organisers will have six months after their registration to choose when to start collecting signatures. More flexibility should benefit smaller groups of organisers in particular. What is most important in this whole process is the fact that the Commission will involve stakeholders in further development and improvements. This system will have superior standards and, most importantly, will be more user friendly. So we are looking forward to implementing all these new features because this is such a great instrument for our citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the mountain has given birth to a mouse, again. The reform of the ECI could have been a great opportunity to respond to a profound need for participation, to those expectations that the reform proposal had generated for European citizens. And yet, once again, the text that emerged from the trialogue frustrates these hopes, the hopes of those who were waiting for an ICE finally effective and effective. Yes, real action on the functionality of the ECI would require an amendment to the Treaties to put an end to the Commission's absurd dual role in the eligibility check and in the decision on whether or not to follow up initiatives. But much more could have been done, however, and above all it could really be opened up to civil society. No, in the face of positive technical adjustments, the text we are voting on even marks a step backwards, giving the Commission a further monopoly, a monopoly on the use and management of the centralised platform instead of those of the organizers, instead of the individual ones, which had worked so well.  Well, I would like to recall, in conclusion, the words of Giorgio Gaber: 'Freedom is participation'. Give civil society greater freedom and give freedom to European citizens.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I welcome the evaluation of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). It’s vitally important that all citizens are involved in quality democratic processes such as the ECI, but that also requires citizenship education and an understanding of European values and EU institutions and how each and every one of us can play a role in shaping the future. The need for better democracy is clear. In the 2016 UK referendum people often did not fully understand what they were voting for, believing themselves to be powerless to shape a better future. Initiatives such as the ECI must be made more accessible to everyone. I particularly welcome the possibility for 16—year—olds to participate and for improved access for people with disabilities. I believe, however, that we must do more. At a recent All Together in Dignity Fourth World event, it was highlighted how poverty acts as a barrier to full citizenship. We must therefore end inequality and social injustice in order to build a more democratic society.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, it is unacceptable for the European Citizens' Initiative to have so many disagreements and so many methodologies from certain political groups. It is a tool of direct democracy. The European Citizens' Initiative will bring us closer to the citizens to hear their voices and it is our duty to respond with action.  Eighty days before the elections, we are putting so many obstacles in the way of the citizens. They want to propose to create legislation for their problems – but what better than that? Why else would they trust us, why would they vote for us when we don't pay attention to them? It is impossible to vote on the text as it is. Unfortunately, the few progressive forces are not enough to overturn the result. Rest assured that some of us will continue to fight and I can guarantee that personally.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, 67 European initiatives have been launched. Only four have met all the criteria, which includes the target of one million signatures. Only two have seen the Commission reply with legislative proposals: Water and sanitation is a human right and Stop glyphosate. Out of those two, neither were considered to have reached a satisfactory outcome by the organisers of the petition.  In the case of the ‘Stop TTIP’ petition, we can clearly see that the Commission refused the initiative because it was counter to their own policy. The Commission gets to be the judge and the judged. This is farcical. But having starved this horse, the Commission now wants to shoot it. It now wants to make it even more difficult to reach the one million signature target by phasing out one of the options to collect them by 2022. The Commission likes to talk about listening to the citizens. Sadly, though, it does anything but. What it’s attempting to do here proves that.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would again like to thank the European Parliament for its vital contribution to this reform of the European Citizens’ Initiative. It is a major step forward for encouraging citizen participation in the democratic life of the European Union. Throughout this mandate, the Commission has shown that when an initiative is successful, we give it all the political attention that it deserves. Citizens’ initiatives now have a very real impact on EU policies and legislation. Europeans will now have an easily accessible and user—friendly tool at their disposal to ask the EU institutions directly to act on the issues that they care about. The revised European Citizens’ Initiative Regulation will make it easier for them to make to themselves heard.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Acting Rapporteur. Mr President, I thank all the colleagues who participated in this very interesting discussion. Our colleague Terricabras has summed up both the added value of this reform and the few concerns that have been expressed here and there. I would say to Vice-President Castaldo that, in fact, there is a misunderstanding about the centralised system with the Commission, because if this system was envisaged and accepted in the trilogue, it was precisely at the request of the candidates to launch the Citizens' Initiative, who absolutely wanted to ensure perfect equality between them. It will be easy to verify that this centralisation is purely technical and that it guarantees gratuitousness, political neutrality and equality among all the launchers of citizen initiatives. I would remind you that once there is an agreement in a trilogue, no more amendments are politically acceptable without having to start from scratch. If that were the case, the matter would be sent back to Parliament next and to the next Commission, and we would have the citizens wait for several more years. Let us not give ourselves the image of a European Parliament which, for five years, has adopted dozens of pieces of legislation, except for the one that aims to give citizens new power!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 March 2019.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Sandra Kalniete, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the state of EU-Russia political relations (A8-0073/2019) (2018/2158(INI)). I would like to inform you that during this debate there will be no catch-the-eye and no blue-card procedure.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the title of my report is ‘On the state of EU-Russia political relations’. It was not an easy task to produce a report on relations in a situation in which the European Union and its associated partners are being attacked by Russian state-sponsored actors that creatively use a wide range of hybrid warfare techniques. As a result, a significant part of the report addresses the resilience of the Union and its ability to deter hybrid threats. Today, five years after the occupation of Crimea, we stress that there will be no return to ‘business as usual’ until Russia fully restores the territorial integrity of Ukraine. We need to reassess the basis of our relations with Russia, as it can no longer be considered a strategic partner. The outdated EU-Russia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement should be reconsidered and any future framework for the EU-Russia relationship should be based on the full observance of international law and OSCE principles. The time for nice diplomatic language is over. Unfortunately, there is no place, space or time for major new cooperation initiatives with Russia. There is very little room for any cooperation so long as Russia continues to occupy parts of Ukraine and hybrid attacks on other European countries continue. We should, however, continue selective engagement with Russia in areas of vital interest to the Union. The global challenges of climate change, energy security, digitalisation, non-proliferation and the fight against terrorism are a few of them. We should stand firm on sanctions, which should be prolonged for as long as Russian violations of international law continue. I advocate a clear message to Russia regarding the sanctions: ‘more for more, less for less’. As we witness serious deterioration in the human rights situation in Russia, the Council has to move on with adopting a European Magnitsky Act, establishing an individual sanctions regime for human rights violations. The key to a more effective EU policy towards Russia is coherence between internal and external policies. This applies in full to Nord Stream 2, a project that reinforces EU dependency on Russian gas supplies, threatens the EU internal market and is not in line with either European energy or foreign and security policy. It needs to be stopped. The report’s list of recommendations for interaction with Russia is rather limited, but some of them should be mentioned: continued support for people-to-people contacts in general – particularly involving civil society activists and with a focus on young people – and a clear code of conduct concerning airspace used by military and civilian aircraft, in order to reduce the risk of misunderstandings, misinterpretation and misreading of each other’s intentions. There can only be political solutions to the conflict in eastern Ukraine and we have to encourage confidence-building measures in the Donbas region across the Line of Contact. The EU has to advance the idea of a UN-led peace operation in this region of eastern Ukraine. To conclude, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs for their team spirit and for the constructive work done on this document.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss Ms Kalniete’s report and to review our relations with Russia, keeping in mind the EU’s five guiding principles set out in 2016. In April 2018, EU Foreign Ministers shared the assessment that the strategic challenges we face in our relations with Russia will persist for some time. As highlighted by rapporteur Kalniete, central to these challenges remains Russia’s violation of international law by the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula and the ongoing destabilisation of eastern Ukraine. The dangerous increase in tensions in the Sea of Azov and the Strait of Kerch is another consequence of the illegal annexation. The Foreign Ministers reconfirmed the relevance of the five guiding principles agreed in 2016 for EU policy towards Russia and highlighted the need to strengthen the resilience of the EU and its neighbours against Russian threats, including hybrid threats. The EU has responded promptly and proactively, to promote EU values and interests and increase EU resilience in line with the five principles. High Representative Mogherini has personally taken every opportunity to raise the EU’s concerns in her meetings with Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov, including the need for progress on the implementation of the Minsk Agreements, the illegal annexation of Crimea and the security situation in both the Sea of Azov and eastern Ukraine. In February 2019, EU Foreign Ministers reiterated the Union’s support for the territorial integrity of Ukraine and its condemnation of the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by Russia. It was also agreed to provide further EU support for Ukrainian regions affected by the situation in the Sea of Azov. We have also raised with Foreign Minister Lavrov international issues such as Syria. We have stressed the need to preserve the ceasefire in Idlib and prevent another humanitarian emergency. We are continuing to discuss not only how to support the western workers in their economic development and EU integration efforts but also Iran and Afghanistan, the need to preserve the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty and the importance of Russia’s remaining in the Council of Europe. The report rightly highlights the fact that the space for civil society in Russia is shrinking and human rights defenders face a difficult situation. The EU delegation in Moscow maintains ongoing close engagement with the Russian authorities on human rights issues, including, among others, the situation of human rights defenders, women’s rights, gender equality, LGBTI persons and Ukrainian prisoners. EU support has been tireless, through frequent contacts with defenders, high-level demarches, media statements, field visits and trial observation. In order to strengthen contacts with the Russian people, the EU continues to maintain an intense level of support. Russian citizens continue to be the largest group of recipients of Schengen visas and Russian students are the largest group of beneficiaries of Erasmus+ exchanges. We will explore further ways to continue to convey the message that the European Union supports the Russian people. We are close to Russia and its people. We share centuries of history and culture, and this will not change, despite any disagreement with the Russian authorities. Russia is an important interlocutor for the EU, and we work well together on various issues, from Iran to the Arctic. Yet we are deeply worried about certain aspects of Russia’s behaviour, not only in Ukraine and Syria but also in Salisbury and in relation to the espionage against the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Following the attack in Salisbury, and in line with the Council conclusions, we have redoubled our efforts to strengthen EU resilience, including in relation to chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear-related risks, and to continue strengthening our capacity to address hybrid threats. A new EU regime against the use and proliferation of chemical weapons was set out in October 2018. In January, the Council imposed sanctions under this new regime, and also against the four Russian GRU (intelligence agency) officials deemed responsible for the attack in Salisbury. Work is ongoing to establish a new EU sanction regime to counter cyber-attacks as part of our wider diplomatic toolbox. We are looking at strengthening our capacity to address the hybrid threats mentioned in the report, including in the areas of cyber-strategy communication and counter-intelligence. We are also reinforcing our work on tackling disinformation. In December 2018, the EU adopted an action plan against disinformation, responding to the European Council’s call for a coordinated response to challenges, particularly with a view to the forthcoming European elections. I know that Parliament will hold a specific discussion about this tomorrow. I will take this opportunity to highlight our common interest in retaining a realistic and balanced approach towards Russia, as underlined by the report. Despite increased tensions, it is essential for the EU to maintain open channels with Russia on issues of strategic interest for Europe and for the world. We will retain a policy of transparency towards Russia and explore cooperation in areas of mutual interest, such as regional connectivity, while also working to support the resilience of partners in the region.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Sandra Kalniete, who worked on this report and on the very welcome update of the incidents between the Union and Russia from the point of view of international relations. Of course, we have had some bad news, which we have already discussed here (for example, the situation in the Kerch Strait and the militarization of the Sea of Azov), but I would rather stress another aspect. As Commissioner has mentioned, we are on the eve of the European elections and we have been hearing for some time about the Kremlin's influence in the political affairs of our democracies. Russia's strong presence is feared and this is not a question of political relations in the foreign sense. I see that the Romanian Presidency of the Council is absent - it is already a habit - and I am therefore speaking to the Commission. Would it be possible to clarify certain points before the European elections: in which democracies is Russia present? Which parties does the Kremlin actually work with? Where is Russian money invested? In my opinion, it would be better if we had this information before the European elections and not after, otherwise we will find ourselves in a situation similar to that of the United States, where there is a post-election crisis due precisely to this uncertainty. Commissioner, do you or do you not want to enlighten us on these points?

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, unfortunately, EU-Russia relations are not in a good shape and the reasons are well known: Russian violations of the principles of international law in Ukraine, the annexation of Crimea, Russia’s support for the extreme right and populist national parties and governments in the EU, such as Mr Orbán in Hungary, and the spread of disinformation and fake news.  In such times of tension, it is important to do everything possible to reduce escalations. Unfortunately, this report doesn’t serve that purpose. The implementation of the Minsk agreements would demonstrate Russia’s goodwill with regard to solving the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We need to engage in consultations with Russia to reduce the risk of misunderstanding. One official platform for such consultations is our interparliamentary dialogue within the EU-Russia delegation. I believe such a dialogue is an important tool just in times of tensions. Therefore, both sides should remove the obstacles for dialogue to take place again.  We need to continue our pragmatic engagement with Russia in areas of common interests and with regard to global governance. The Northern Dimension initiative, cross-border cooperation and the Barents Euro-Arctic Council are good examples for constructive engagement that benefits citizens.  It is really important that we step up the protection of human rights defenders. For people-to people-contact, Erasmus+ is highly popular and its funding needs to be increased.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Russia promises when it is forced to do so. And he does not keep his promises as soon as he gains strength. These words were spoken 100 years ago by a great Pole, Józef Piłsudski. Generations of Poles and other peoples of my part of Europe have confirmed this with their fate. Today, these words were confirmed after 2008 in Georgia, after 2014 in Ukraine, in the Middle East, in the Arctic, in Russia against its own society and many other places. I support Sandra Kalniete's report and thank you very much for your cooperation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I am very pleased that we can talk here tonight about the political relations between Europe and Russia. We should not hide it: the relationship between Europe and Russia is not good, and that is probably an understatement.  We now have fewer contacts with Russia and we negotiate less with Russia than in the cold war times. That should make us think about how to deal with this reality, taking into account the fact that we have been in a political deadlock of sanctions and counter-sanctions for five years. The dialogue is far to be seen.  In order to break this deadlock, I can tell you that the ALDE Group has drawn up a very nice paper on a new Russia strategy. A strategy in which we put the entire EU Russia relationship in a broader perspective. A strategy that leaves the door open to dialogue, because Russia is and remains Europe's great neighbour. A strategy based on conditional engagement, based on the Helsinki process of the 1970s, through parallel processes where, each time progress is made in one domain, cooperation is initiated in another domain, not just looking at economic sanctions in relation to the Minsk agreements. A strategy in which we reach out unconditionally – and I think this is very important – to the Russian citizens and civil society.  You know, ladies and gentlemen, at the moment a whole generation of Russians are growing up with anti-European sentiments. That worries me, and that is why it is important that we send a signal here in the European Parliament, that we need to look at dialogue and that we should set up cooperation where it is needed.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would prefer good relations with the citizens of Russia. But I also know what is against it: the occupation of Crimea, the ongoing war against Ukraine, which has now killed 13 000 people, a passenger plane that was shot down, the misery of the people of Donbass, the re-expulsion of the Crimean Tatars from Crimea, and show trials in Russia, in which Ukrainian marines are currently threatened with psychiatric treatment. Putin's aggression is not directed solely against Ukraine, but rather our eastern partner states Moldova and Georgia were affected by this aggression even before the war against Ukraine. And we have now seen that the aggression is also directed against the European Union. I have to say that, for me, conventional, and even more so the nuclear armament, which Russia systematically pursues, underlines this aggression against the European Union. The financing of anti-European parties on the far right, but also on the left, interference in EU referendums, cyberattacks, snipering in Macedonia and, more recently, on French roads in connection with the yellow vests, poison-killing attacks – these are all not invitations with which Russia would promote a return to better relations. Human rights violations in Russia against civil rights activists, opposition journalists and minorities are commonplace. The European Court of Human Rights, the Council of Europe and also the European Parliament have taken decisions and adopted resolutions that have so far been without consequences. We do indeed want a better relationship with Russian citizens. We want Russia to remain in the Council of Europe, but the conditions must be right.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has  Indeed, EU-Russia bilateral relations are at their lowest level since 1990, and they continue to stumble towards the abyss. We are faced with a decision in principle: how do we want to ensure peace and partnership relations with Russia in the interests of solving serious problems on our continent in the immediate vicinity, Mrs Harms, the EU and Russia, and also our responsibility for conflicts in other regions of the world in the future? The experience of the 20th century, but also of the last two decades, teaches us that stability and peace, solutions to all the different interests of actors involved are not opposed, but only to be implemented with Russia. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, we discussed in the report whether relations should be based on mutual deterrence. I stand by this: this is wrong! We are maneuvering deeper and deeper into speechlessness and dead-end. In view of the tensions, arms races and a growing political and military confrontation, a factual, critical and results-oriented dialogue guide must be tackled and developed without preconditions, including the lifting of the reciprocal sanctions regimes, which often exist instead of parliamentary cooperation. The EU should supplement its perfectly justified critical assessment of Russia's domestic and foreign policy with a self-critical analysis of its own policies. And I also expect this from all political leaders in the Russian Federation.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I don’t support what Russia has done in the Crimea, or its recent actions in the Sea of Azov, and I don’t see why anyone who’s gay would want to live under a regime that oppresses gay people. I don’t want to see Oleg Sentsov still in jail as a political prisoner. This year, Russia has entered the Open Doors World Watch List, a list of nations which do the most persecution of Christians on the planet, a fact that hasn’t made it into the report. I can’t believe for one second that Russian officers just happened to be visiting Salisbury Cathedral at the time of the Novichok attack, so don’t expect me to have anything positive to say about the Putin regime in Russia. It seems to me that a large chunk of Russia’s foreign policy approach is the nation-state equivalent of trolling. They’re trying to provoke us into overreacting to the wrong things, they’re trying to wrong-foot us, and it seems to me that in this House some people are falling for it hook, line, and sinker. And this notion that Russia was meddling in the British referendum campaign is nonsense. During the campaign, Facebook tells us that Russian operatives spent 97 cents – that’s US cents, about 80 euro cents – on political advertising, and even that was a mistake because it was material targeted at an American audience that missed. Putin wants to be the villain of the piece. It suits his strategy to do so. It suits the interests of this place to try to claim that there was something up with the British referendum because frankly you don’t like the result. There were indeed some accidental rule breaches on both sides in the British referendum campaign. The pro-EU Lib Dems were fined, the pro-EU Open Britain were fined for rule breaches. Some other allegations were simply not followed up on. Nothing, though, was material to the outcome as per the UK Court of Appeal ruling of 4 March. There is no evidence that gives rise to any soundly based grounds for believing the outcome of the referendum would have been different if those breaches had not occurred. The very fact that this constant assault on the referendum result and upon British democracy in general is being recycled time and time again, shows a pathological reluctance to accept the will of the British people.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Mrs. Kalniete, you were a child of the gulag. I understand that you are acting against this system, because you have suffered it in your flesh. I myself fought the communist system, because it is essentially based on lies. However, we must not confuse two things: on the one hand a system and on the other hand a country. The Russians were the first to suffer the evils of Stalinism as well. In many institutions, Bolshevism, we ourselves are not exempt. Therefore, when we adopt a certain strategy vis-à-vis Russia, do not see it as a bad hand. France, Germany, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, even, sometimes simply see their interest, and this goes in the direction of Europe. It would be completely wrong, and these are Bolshevik methods, to consider that populist movements are a fifth column... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, I conclude that we all share a common interest in retaining a united and realistic approach towards Russia. We will continue to look at how best to use all the instruments available to us in strengthening our own resilience, supporting our partners, continuing political exchanges in selected issues and supporting Russian civil society, human rights and democracy, and people-to-people contacts.  May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Chair of the Sitting! I would like to thank all my colleagues who took part in the resolution today. It is resigned to be noted that, compared to the resolution of similar content adopted by the European Parliament in 2015, relations between the European Union and Russia have not improved, but have deteriorated, and I see no basis for the hope that, in the future, the Kremlin could change its ideology and strategy aimed at destabilising the European Union and russia's self-isolation. This weekend there were widespread protests in Moscow and Vorone, against the Kremlin's intention to isolate the Russian Internet from the rest of the world. This is another sign of how much the Putin regime fears the diversity of information, because it is aware that openness is a threat to the existence of the regime. If the collapse of the USSR, in Putin's words, was the biggest geopolitical disaster of the 20th century, then the course chosen by the Kremlin for the isolation of the Russian state and the people could lead to the greatest geopolitical disaster of the 21st century. We must therefore leave the illusion in Europe that we will be able to return to the hopeful state of cooperation that developed between the European Union and Russia after the fall of the Iron Curtain. Unfortunately, this will not happen so soon, certainly not during Putin's reign. We must accept this reality and, accordingly, develop our policy in our relations with Russia.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 March 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – Today it is a very symbolic day to have these debates in the plenary. Twenty-nine years ago, on 11th March, Lithuania regained its independence from the Soviet Union and started its freedom and democracy chapter. Therefore, I fully support my colleague Kalniete and her own—initiative report. It is crucial to talk loud about Russia’s military interventions into Ukraine’s – an independent country’s – territory. These cruel, anti—democratic actions are happening right across the European border. Therefore, the EU should express its full support for Ukraine. The EU cannot and should not return to ‘business as usual’ with Russia until that country fully implements the Minsk Agreement and restores the territorial integrity of Ukraine. This message should be sent to Putin loud and clear. Therefore, I call on the EU to strengthen sanctions for Russia, especially from the economic point of view. Russia’s aggression has to be stopped.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Firstly, I would like to emphasise that Russia has not implemented more than 1 000 judgments of the European Court of Human Rights. This shows that Russia is not fulfilling its international obligations under its membership of the Council of Europe. So the question is, does Russia want to be part of a civilized world at all? Secondly, I am pleased that the European Parliament is clearly calling on the Member States to end the so-called golden visa and passport schemes for the richest, which are also used by Russian oligarchs. "Golden visas" are investor-friendly schemes that entitle a third-country national to reside in a Member State but also to travel freely within the Schengen area. It is currently issued by 20 EU countries: Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Greece, Spain, The Netherlands, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Latvia, Malta, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, the United Kingdom and Italy. Gold passports, on the other hand, are schemes for granting citizenship to investors under less stringent conditions than usual, e.g. you do not have to physically reside in a country or have any other real connection with it. "Golden passports" are issued by Bulgaria, Malta and Cyprus and cost between one million and two million euros. Golden visas and passports pose a threat to the EU as they create conditions conducive to money laundering, corruption and tax evasion and can undermine the effectiveness of international sanctions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is a short presentation of the report by Soraya Post, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation (A8-0075/2019) (2018/2159(INI)).

name: Soraya POST
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the European Union is, at its core, a peace project. As such, we must remain committed to reinforcing our role as a global actor for peace. The main idea of the report is to reinforce the institutional capacities of the EU for conflict prevention and mediation, as well as to increase the role of the European Parliament in this area. Our most important suggestions are to establish an EU High—Level Advisory Board on conflict prevention and mediation under the Vice President/High Representative. This advisory board will set up a pool of senior political mediators and conflict prevention experts. A High—Level Advisory Board for the EU also reflects what the UN has successfully put in place under the new Secretary-General. We also need an EU Special Envoy for Peace. There is indeed a need for a clear mandate on how to build and promote peace at all levels in the world. Furthermore, the establishment of additional institutional mechanisms, such as task forces for specific conflict prevention situations, are also important aspects on how to strengthen the institutional capacities for conflict prevention and mediation. These horizontal mechanisms are a very effective and pragmatic approach to coordinate EU institutional work on the ground. The establishment of a dedicated Council working group on conflict prevention and mediation is also a tool put forward in the report. The Council must put conflict prevention and mediation high on its agenda and step up its work through focused and informed measures.  When it comes to the European Parliament, its growing role in political mediation processes – notably via DEG activities – is more and more recognised. The report also suggests the appointment of a Vice—President responsible for coordinating the mediation and facilitation of dialogue activities. A yearly report to Parliament on the progress made in implementing EU policy commitments on conflict prevention and mediation is also requested. Additionally, I have been clear on the budget issues. If we want the EU to act and to be efficient on conflict prevention and mediation, we absolutely need to ensure that the new MFF will foresee sufficient and earmarked financial resources.  We must also see the fundamental logic of the active work and representation of women with women’s experiences, youth and civil society at all stages of conflict prevention and mediation work. This is why I put great effort into mainstreaming the gender perspective in the report, in line with the internationally accepted Women, Peace and Security (WPS) Agenda. This i reinforced by the EU in the conclusions adopted by the Council on women, peace and security just a few months ago, in December 2018. In their conclusions, the Council recalls the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to full implementation of the WPS Agenda, which consists of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 and its follow-up resolutions, ensuring that the 1325 agenda is fully integrated into all EU policies and efforts. I am very surprised by the fact that gender mainstreaming was not accepted by a majority in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET). In order to rebalance the report, I have now put forward amendments for the plenary on the following topics: to call for the EU to take a lead role in the implementation of the UN Security Council resolution on women, peace and security; in the systematic establishment of a reconciliation and accountability mechanism; in the establishment of a pool of mediators that includes current and former members of the European Parliament; and in the establishment of a European women’s mediator network, and in gender budgeting.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, on Friday 8 March, we celebrated International Women’s Day, so I took the opportunity to reflect on the situation of women in conflict zones who suffer from attacks on their human rights and physical and mental health. On a wider scale, millions of women around the world have been, are, and will be, victims of gender-based violence. The EU must be at the forefront of preventing and tackling violence against women and must encourage a holistic approach to dismantling all gender-based discrimination and violence, and this must go hand in hand with effective awareness raising and education for men and women on gender equality and human and women’s rights. However, none of these tools can be effectively shaped and implemented without the direct involvement of women from all backgrounds, as gender-based violence takes many forms. I believe it’s crucial, when building policies to protect women, that we involve many organisations from civil society, who are doing extraordinary work helping women in difficult situations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, conflict prevention and mediation must be an important action of the European Union since it is an international player, a soft power, which must act on the basis of the principles of peaceful coexistence. Of course, the European Union must formulate values and principles. The basic principle is, first of all, the consolidation of the principle of non-interference within each Member State. Secondly, the mutual economic benefit. Thirdly, support for and respect for international law and UN resolutions. Fourthly, respect for human rights. Fifthly, the peaceful resolution of disputes on the basis of the UN Charter. Moreover, it must pursue parliamentary diplomacy, because in this way there can really be rapprochement with other states and a dispute resolution can be initiated. But the most important thing is to address the causes of conflict and, of course, there must be a human-centred approach on the part of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President I would like to warmly welcome the report on building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation. As rapporteur Post rightly points out, conflict prevention and mediation are core issues of our daily work, which we are actively prioritising as also spelled out in our Global Strategy. Today the EU is involved in some 40 mediation and ILO processes worldwide and in some of them the EU is in the lead and its efforts is clearly visible. In other cases, and deliberately so, we are working more discreetly. In response to the impact of conflicts on our societies, we need to redouble our conflict-prevention efforts and to enhance mediation as a first response to tensions. Conflict prevention and mediation is an important priority for the European External Action Service (EEAS). The ongoing work has, for example, entailed active participation by the EU in the international mediation efforts accompanying the ongoing peace process in Mali. We are also building the capacity of parties in conflict to move towards peace in the Central African Republic. One further example is our support for women mediators who work at the front lines in Yemen and Syria to play a meaningful role in helping to make peace a reality. At the same time, we work very closely with our regional partners such as the United Nations, the African Union, the OSCE and others, by supporting their mediation work. As conflicts around the world increase both in number and complexity, we need more than ever to cooperate and complement each other. We also regularly convene meetings with the Member States and invite the European Parliament to share our insights and enhance our collective work by creating a common approach on mediation. As part of planning to enhance EEAS mediation capacities, an internal pool of mediators which can be deployed on behalf of the EU is being set up. Furthermore, a high-level interinstitutional and mediation taskforce – which should provide guidance for high-profile mediation assignments, risk assessments and enhanced cooperation – is being launched. It is sometimes difficult to demonstrate the success of mediation and conflict prevention activities that are often conducted discreetly. The demand for mediation and conflict prevention has risen exponentially and the mediation field is developing fast in response to the changing nature of conflicts. The EU shouldn’t only want to keep up with the pace of efforts, but should want to lead in this field, and we are working hard to make this possible. I count on your support to ensure that we will have dedicated and earmarked resources in the next Multiannual Financial Framework to further step up the EU’s role in conflict prevention and mediation. Let me commend rapporteur Post and all of you for this important report, which covers the pertinent issues very well. I hope that we will continue to work closely on these matters.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: We will of course, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 12 March 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. – We had a good chance to make a report, which would give clear instructions to such an important issue as conflict prevention and mediation. The EU needs to have its capacities in these areas ready and checked. We are surrounded by countries, where the skills and methodology in conflict resolution or mediation could not only save lives, but also contribute to a safer, more stable and peaceful environment. Mediation and conflict prevention should become an integral part of our external action. The EU is well known for using soft power, by developing further the framework and methodology and capacities for the mediation work. In this respect we should be enhancing our capacities and improve inter-institutional cooperation and communication. All EU institutions which work in this area should have a common joint approach. As an MEP with substantial experience in mediation, I would like to stress the positive role that the Parliament started to play in facilitation and mediation of political crises. We have good results in Ukraine and North Macedonia through Jean Monnet Dialogues. We should be building up on these successful practices.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, this year marks the 30th anniversary of the fall of communism in Central and Eastern Europe, which has also led to the reunification of the European continent. In Romania, unlike the other states of Central and Eastern Europe, the fall of communism resulted in human casualties, with more than 1,100 people losing their lives in December 1989. What is less well known, however, is that on 2 March 1989, Mr. Liviu Cornel Babeş set himself on a ski slope in Romania in protest of the communist regime and its horrors. On 2 March 1989, Mr. Liviu Cornel Babeş set himself on the ski slope of Brasov, a public place frequented by many foreign tourists, which made it impossible for the Communists to conceal this gesture of protest. It is very important to remember this martyr hero, because he allowed and opened the series of revolutions of 1989, which led to democracy in Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this evening I am taking to you the voice of the citizens of marche, the voice of those who trusted EUR 248 million of public money and a priority axis of intervention identified ad hoc to support the earthquake-stricken areas of the Marche region.  Instead, the region's ERDF POR, agreed with the European Commission following the 2016 and 2017 earthquakes, provided for that money to go primarily to the area of the 87 municipalities of the crater, in order to provide support to the affected populations and the activities of the territory.  We all know how much we need it, but we get disconcerting news. It seems that the regional council has decided to use a large part of that money for interventions in the rest of the region. One example above all: out of the EUR 45 million allocated to strategic buildings, to health buildings, EUR 23 million went outside the affected areas.  We want to get to the bottom of this. Mrs Agea and I will put a question to the Commission to shed light on the allocation of these funds. It is not acceptable that the huge damage should also be caused by mockery. We and the citizens of marche want the truth.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, a few days ago in the Eastern Mediterranean, new natural gas deposits were found, in the Cypriot EEZ, in the EEZ of the Republic of Cyprus. This creates positive prospects for the implementation of the European Union's energy plans with dependence on third countries, and for stability in the wider region, with states within the European Union, but also states outside the European Union.  At the same time, however, Turkey is increasing its aggression, with new threats, and is conducting the largest naval exercise in its history in the Eastern Mediterranean, as it boasts. The Turkish Ministry of Defence has even published a map illegally presenting the Republic of Cyprus, a Member State of the European Union, as an extension of Turkey; In other cases, we have imposed sanctions – in the case of Cyprus we stick to the resolutions. When are we going to react to the raider? To have credibility, sanctions are imposed on Turkey and an arms embargo.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to draw attention to the dangers and consequences of corruption. I am afraid that many people consider this to be a theoretical problem, which is a good thing to say in damning sentences, but then we often settle for half-solutions and say that this phenomenon is indestructible. I am a citizen of Slovakia and, as such, I had to be shocked to learn of the way in which the governing coalition, which is still in power, is using corruption as a way of working. This toleration was distorted to the point where a journalist was killed in our country, who revealed corruption cases, and it became clear that criminal groups were preparing to kill a prosecutor, the deputy attorney general and the former minister of justice. I would therefore like to draw attention to the fact that it is not only necessary to investigate individual abuses, but also to crush the intertwining of the underworld and politics and to avoid corruption becoming part of our political systems. Thank you very much.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the Paris Agreement and the Emissions Trading System, the European Union has set a clear course for reducing climate-changing emissions that are harmful to human health. In Taranto, in the city of the two seas, in the south of Italy, meanwhile, there are increases in emissions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons by 105 %. In Taranto children die, schools close, the right to education and health is denied and one is forced to choose between work and health, while the Italian Government does not follow the implementation of the Ilva agreement, does not implement the institutional development contract, does not preside over the verification of environmental and employment data and does not take action to use the resources available to the extraordinary administration. I ask the Commission to support any technically founded proposal by the Puglia region to sign a programme agreement for Taranto, similar to the one signed with the Calais region, in which resources of EUR 1 billion had been committed to promote the low-carbon economy in the region.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, after the natural disaster and the floods that hit the regional unit of Chania, today's refusal by the Eurogroup to return one billion euros to Greece, from the European Central Bank's profits on Greek bonds, thus proving, once again, that the harsh supervision of the troika and the lenders over the poor Greek people continues.  The European Central Bank profited unashamedly against Greece, buying Greek bonds at a discount of 40 % and then demanding and achieving the repayment of these bonds at face value, thus earning over 20 billion euros. As if that were not enough, Draghi is now demanding the sale of red loans to crows instead of a lentil plate, so greeks are in danger of losing their homes. The only solution is the creation of a Government-intervention Borrowers' Salvation Fund, which will buy the red loans at the first offer price made by the crows. This is the position and should apply in particular to the regional unit of Chania, which has been affected by the floods.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Mr President, we have eleven years left to act against climate change, international scientists and thousands of young people on the streets say, the same young people as the right ones refused to invite this week. Normal! They're afraid they'll leave their classes to give us a master lesson.  The Greens have reopened the doors of Parliament which you have closed to them and here they are, in Parliament, demanding political action in the face of the climate emergency, because we are still in time for a transition that is ecological, just, fast, participatory, creative and ambitious, that creates opportunities without leaving anyone behind and that gives a future to our youth.  This Friday there will be a climate 15-M throughout Europe and we better listen and act because otherwise, as Greta Thunberg says, we will be remembered as the greatest villains in this story. And I refuse, because I want to be able to look my daughters in the eye.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Romania has the honour, but also the capacity, to hold the rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union at a crucial time for the European project. How are we doing? If, before President Iohannis took office, the opposition, even the former Finnish Prime Minister, said that we were not ready today, just over two months after taking office, all European partners appreciate at least three things. The political will and seriousness of the Romanian government and the quality of the solutions identified for unlocking key files. In short, the political desire to carry forward the European project. Secondly, we demonstrate impeccable administrative capacity with regard to the organisation of events and debates within the rotating presidency and the technical training of all the specialists involved. Last but not least, we show the true face of our country. Romania is a beautiful country, with serious, hardworking and pro-European people. Here we have done our homework, and even though we have four months to hand over the baton, we can say that it is a successful presidency. He can see the opposition, he can see Iohannis, between a ski tour and the election campaign for another term.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, the Czech Republic and Poland have been in dispute for several weeks. At the beginning of the affair, salmonella is found in approximately 700 kilograms of beef delivered to the Czech Republic. I have respect for all The Member States and especially those with whom we are in the Visegrad Four, so I would like to shed some light on the czech republic's progress. I find it perfectly logical that the Czech authorities proceeded to the inspections of Polish beef after the discovery. It wasn't a move we wanted to shame our neighbor with. It was just an effort to protect ourselves. Citizens of the Czech Republic cannot eat dangerous and poor quality products. However, I completely reject the rude way in which the EU, which demands the abolition of controls, has become embroiled in the matter. The Czech Republic only wants evidence of the presence of veterinary supervision during slaughter and of sufficient hygiene of operations during meat production. This is a perfectly rational requirement from which it is not possible to retreat. The EU must respect our right and protect us and should not discourage us from doing so.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, tonight the negotiations on what may be the Brexit end game are taking place in rooms below us and all around us. In any negotiations, there may be some need for what we might call constructive ambiguity, but there are red lines that cannot be crossed. In this context, I am heartened by the earlier comments from the chief Parliament negotiator, Mr Guy Verhofstadt, where he once again reiterated his pledge to stand by Ireland and support the Good Friday Agreement. However, I must say I am somewhat concerned by reports that the implementation of the backstop, which is the insurance policy guaranteeing no hardening of the border in Ireland, may be outsourced to some independent body and that somewhere in that process, the UK might unilaterally walk away from the backstop. We all hope the backstop will never need to be implemented, and if it is, it will be temporary, but that can only happen by agreement. There can be no Houdini-like smoke screen that would ever, ever allow unilateral action by the UK to end the backstop.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, last week a very, very far-right Spanish group, VOX, obtained permission from President Tajani to organise an event in the European Parliament. A few days earlier, the president himself had banned an act by Catalan Presidents Torra and Puigdemont for apparent security reasons.  So far, the president has not yet responded to our legitimate request to be able to view the security reports mentioned. The ones that require the most security are those of VOX, who in that session threatened a Flemish MEP, who was really afraid, and who was told "you and I hit him". To see that the President of Parliament trusts VOX more than the democratically elected Catalan presidents alarms me in case he is a harbinger of a blacker future in this house. I hope not. As I hope you can live here with other leaders, with other criteria and, of course, with less far-right accepted and recognized. But I don't know if we'll be so lucky.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation of Christians has deteriorated in recent years. According to The Help the Church in Need, 200 million Christians suffer from brutal persecution, and 350 million suffer various forms of discrimination. In 2018, forty missionaries and missionaries were killed. In Strasbourg in January, we voted on a report on the Union guidelines and the mandate of the Special Envoy on the promotion of religious freedom outside the Union. However, also as Christians living in the European Union, we are forced to defend our defence, especially because of regulations and documents issued by the UN and the European Parliament promoting so-called sexual and reproductive health with the enforcement of childhood sex education, the legalisation of abortion, contraceptives and the acceptance of same-sex relationships, which for Catholics are unacceptable to nature and to God. Forcing such a law to be implemented is violent and persecuted, which is why I call for freedom and respect for rights. (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 20 February Romania took another important step by adopting the copyright directive in the digital single market, a legislative act that was one of the most difficult dossiers under discussion at European level. The agreement of the Member States obtained by Romania at the meeting of the Committee of Permanent Representatives demonstrates that Romania has managed to achieve a fair compromise, which will allow the modernisation of the current copyright legislative framework, in line with developments in the digital market. By obtaining this agreement, the Romanian Government demonstrates that, despite all the allegations, it is a government capable of carrying out the tasks of the rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, a year ago we condemned in this House the murder of the councillor of PSOL Marielle Franco. A year later, we're still justiceless.  This was not just any crime, it was a preview of the homophobic and racist threat that shakes Brazil today. We demand that the authorities ensure an impartial investigation and identify the intellectual perpetrators of Marielle Franco's crime. We demand the cessation of violence and political persecution in Brazil. We demand protection for the rest of the social and political leaders in Brazil sought to defend the interests of the popular classes.  The Brazilian State must be responsible for the security of all political representatives and human rights defenders. Defending justice for Marielle is to ensure that no other companions are assaulted or murdered.  From the European Parliament we want to join the cry of 'Marielle present!'.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I believe that healthcare is a universal right. However, Brexit has put that common good in jeopardy for EU nationals in the UK and for British nationals who live in the other 27 Member States. I welcome the UK’s belated initiative, which requires my Government to seek a joint UK—EU commitment to preserving citizens’ rights in the withdrawal agreement, whatever the outcome of negotiations. This would ensure that our families can continue to access healthcare and social security as before. The Commission has recommended that Member States adopt a generous approach, but I implore national governments to go further and guarantee those rights – because they are founded on European values. Finally, a word about the mental health of people whose lives have been made unbearable because of Brexit uncertainty. As Theresa May dines with Mr Juncker tonight, she would do well to reflect on her role in destroying the well—being of millions.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, the murder of a woman yesterday in my country changed the subject of my statement because women stop at the world as it did on 8 March, in which millions of women took to the streets to remember that our rights are not negotiable, to defend them and to fight against inequality.  We are the daughters, granddaughters, sisters, neighbors and friends of those who suffer sexist violence. We live in a world of prejudice that discredits our word. We live on alert when we go home alone. We suffer the labor cause because we are women, we have less wages and less recognition for our work.  Our body is political because they want to decide for him, for ourselves. They want to make us invisible and silence our voice like they silenced the two women murdered last week. This is gender-based violence that some political parties want to deny. And the European Parliament must continue to call for an investment in the fight against gender-based violence.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union means access to development, but also respect for all Member States. We are all concerned about the future of the European Union, and the elections that will take place soon must be proof that this project can regain the trust received from the people. The European Union must mean a better life for its citizens, more freedom, equity and prosperity, not fear and no terror. Europeans must feel that they are part of a family, that they have common values, but that are also respected in their particularities. I look with confidence at President Macron's signal that the Union is a project that must benefit all European citizens, and all Member States must have the same rights. It is a signal that announces a Union without concentric circles or inequalities between Member States, and it is very important that the issue of the social security of European citizens is brought back to the fore.  Only in this way, by listening to everyone, taking into account all the arguments, without blocking or threatening, can we put an end to the unfortunate developments of the European Union.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, one of the most moving places I have visited is the Holocaust Memorial in Berlin, the memorial to the murdered Jews of Europe. When I visited several years ago, I could not have imagined that today, several years on and well into the 21st century, anti-Semitism would have again become a cause of deep worry, fear and dread in Europe. The difficult, sickening truth is that it has, and it is. It is doing so in the most grotesque, frightening and upsetting ways possible: significant increases in anti-Semitic incidents across Europe in recent years. The Fundamental Rights Agency’s report on this last year shows conclusions that are alarming and frightening beyond words.  This vile hatred in all its forms must be confronted online, on the right, on the left, inside political parties, across political debate and in wider society. We must be uncompromising, unrelenting, tenacious and urgent in our response.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, Ms May has arrived in Strasbourg this evening for yet another meeting with Mr Juncker. How many times will she plead for the worst possible terms she can get? The last two years and nine months have been an elaborate charade designed to propagandise the British people into believing that leaving the EU is just too difficult, and this is just the latest scene in the drama.  We are being positioned, at best, for a sham exit. This whole process has been about arriving at a so-called deal whereby we leave in name only. If our treacherous Prime Minister and political class cannot prevent Brexit altogether, they at least intend to position us for re—entry as quickly as possible. Whatever betrayal agreement Ms May agrees, it will not be the end of the story. It will just begin the next phase of the British people’s struggle to leave the European Union.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, 400 000 households in Ireland are in fuel poverty. Deprivation levels for single-parent families have doubled over the last five years, yet we have talk of a hike in a carbon tax. A carbon tax is a false solution and a distraction. All the while corporate polluters are let off the hook and continue to extract fossil fuels. Is it any wonder that companies like BP, Shell and ExxonMobil are fans? Rapid, far—reaching and unprecedented change is what the IPCC report called for, and instead we are discussing carbon tax top—ups that punish ordinary families. Instead, we should be closing the corporate tax loopholes and introducing a wealth tax to frontload the investment in sustainable alternatives and set a timeline for fossil fuel phase—out.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the French press has just revealed that almost all European political parties, with the exception of the ENL, are financed by multinationals. This is particularly the case for the centrist ALDE party, to which President Macron is soft-eyed. ALDE received 122,000 euros from eight multinationals, including Bayer, Uber and Google, in 2018. The case of Bayer is particularly edifying: Bayer, an agrochemical giant that wants to place agriculture under the dependence of its GMO seeds. Bayer, which employs 13 full-time employees and spends 2 million euros a year on lobbying purposes in Brussels alone. Bayer, who supplied Zyklon B to the Nazis and who, during World War II, bought deported women from Auschwitz to make guinea pigs. That is where the money that funds ALDE comes from. Mr. Macron, sweep your door before giving moral lessons to the National Rally and its allies!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On the first of March, we celebrated the Day of Remembrance of The Fallen Soldiers in Poland. They were soldiers of the Polish underworld, who fought first against the Nazi occupation, and then for many years after the war resisted the communist regime imposed on us by the Soviets, and paid it mostly with life. In this context, I would like to say that I am terribly ashamed that communism is still taken seriously in our parliament. In the 21st century, when, long after the war, national socialism was put out of circulation, beyond the margins of political life, communism is still taken seriously and communist party representatives sit in this chamber and shamelessly sit, not somewhere as social outcasts, but as representatives of a large political group. Such people should not be given a hand, and in the meantime they are normally respected here. This offends the memory of our ancestors who fought the Communists. Some were victims of the most criminal system, the most criminal ideology in human history, which is communism.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I declare closed the 2018-2019 session of the European Parliament.
